nose: Fresh tangerines, pineapple slices, hazelnut praline, sweet vanilla, crème caramel and subtly floral notes.
palate: Ripe pear, sweet orange marmalade, coconut shavings, creamy vanilla and toasted almonds.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Coconut, Pineapple, Orange, Oak, Almond Fresh tangerines, pineapple slices, hazelnut praline, sweet vanilla, crème caramel and subtly floral notes. Ripe pear, sweet orange marmalade, coconut shavings, creamy vanilla and toasted almonds. Silky with enduring sweet oakiness.

name: Tamdhu 15 Year OldSherry Cask Matured
characters: Apricot, Orange, Almond, Malt, Cream, Sherry
reviews: Best 15 year old Speyside Sherry. || Super good! Better than the Macallan. || Excellent. Rich and flavourful. The sherry finish really comes through. || Amazing whisky with a great and long-lasting finish.
flavour_note: Apricot, Orange, Almond, Malt, Cream, Sherry

name: Glenfarclas 15 Year OldCheltenham Festival Edition
characters: Dark Chocolate, Walnut, Plums, Toffee, Figs, Fruit Cake
flavour_note: Dark Chocolate, Walnut, Plums, Toffee, Figs, Fruit Cake

name: Glenfarclas 12 Year Old
reviews: I get quite a bit of banana. Also caramel is a nice note on the finish. A lovely whisky for the price. || It has almost no other taste than alchohol. No oak, almost no sweetnes. A faint hint of smoke. No nose and no aftertaste. For a 12 year old spirit this is really bad. || This is just delightful. A gorgeous nose, one of the best I've come across - sherry & dried fruit. The body is rich, lovely viscosity, and more of the sherry, fruit and - to my buds - a bit of coconut. The finish is warming, slightly spice (from the oak, nothing too prominent) and a touch of caramel. No alcohol notes whatsoever, despite being 43%. I went through this one in a hurry. || Simply Amazing! || A bit disappointing, this one! Not nearly as full-flavoured as 15 and older, though same colour as 18, which is odd. Just lacking that usual toasty bite of a Glenfarclas which I love!!! Hopefully will improve as bottle progresses. Good value overall though!
flavour_note: Honey, Apple, Raisins, Nutmeg, Cinnamon

name: Cragganmore 12 Year Old
nose: A combination of sweet floral fragrances, riverside herbs and flowers with some honey and vanilla.
palate: A strong malty taste with hints of sweet wood smoke and sandalwood.
finish: A long, malt-driven finish with light smoke and hints of sweetness.
reviews: A reference whisky for the honey/fruit/floral flavour profile. An affordable introduction for new drinkers, but will personally continue with the excellent Dalwhinnie 15 for this particular style. || Quality whiskey but not my taste, its more sweet with no tones of smoke. || Typical floral/honeyed Speysider.Nothing stands out to give it a wow factor.Easily drinkable but it wouldn't be my first weapon of choice.2.75/3 || Very smooth taste. My wife who is a non whiskey drinker likes it. No smokiness but a lovely rich finish. || Really tasty whiskey. Would definitely recommend.
flavour_note: Almond, Toffee, Biscuits, Lemon, Orange A combination of sweet floral fragrances, riverside herbs and flowers with some honey and vanilla. A strong malty taste with hints of sweet wood smoke and sandalwood. A long, malt-driven finish with light smoke and hints of sweetness.

name: Macallan Rare Cask2023 Release
reviews: Excellent. Body a 4 rich 3. Sweet 2/3. Overal a great scotch. Maybe their best 18

name: Glenburgie 199628 Year Old Connoisseurs Choice for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Vanilla, Coconut, Milk Chocolate, Melon, Honey
nose: Desiccated coconut with milk chocolate aromas lead to vanilla pod and butterscotch.
palate: Tropical fruit flavours combine with heather honey, cantaloupe melon and malted cereal.
finish: A medium length, nutty finish with citrus.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Coconut, Milk Chocolate, Melon, Honey Desiccated coconut with milk chocolate aromas lead to vanilla pod and butterscotch. Tropical fruit flavours combine with heather honey, cantaloupe melon and malted cereal. A medium length, nutty finish with citrus.

name: Benriach The Twelve12 Year Old
characters: Raisins, Sultana, Fruit Cake, Nutmeg, Cinnamon, Apple
reviews: Fragrant and full-bodied. Juicy and sweet. Sherry dominates over port, but still nice. || Sweet notes and smooth feel. Very impressed || Very flavoursome whisky, overall very easy to drink neat! Was bought as a present for me and I definitely will be buying some for myself in the future || This is a wonderful whisky beautiful almost rosey red colour. Smooth and easy to drink. Lovely and sweet if you like sweet whisky’s. Probably due to a little spice it’s initially got a slight strong taste when first drinking it but the spicy taste subsides fairly quickly and leaves a pretty pleasant taste not long after.I agree with the previous reviewer if you add a little water into it it may tend to negate the spice just a little and open up the sweeter taste a little. a great whisky to recommended especially if you like sweet whisky. || This is a superb whisky, full flavoured and a delight on the palate, very complex to say the least and a good hit of honey and spice i will definitely be buying more of this for sure
flavour_note: Raisins, Sultana, Fruit Cake, Nutmeg, Cinnamon, Apple

name: Mortlach 201410 Year Old Bolgheri Cask Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Dried Fruit, Dates, Toffee, Malt, Honey, Raisins
nose: Rich and fruity, with black cherries, blackcurrants and redcurrants joined by nectarines. Dark chocolate and brown sugar follow, with hints of black liquorice and chocolate brownie.
palate: Thick, with a background of spice. Thick chocolate fudge cake emerges, studded with singed raisins and red-fruit jam. more savoury than expected from the nose.
finish: Long and warming, with black cherry, chocolate fudge and gentle aniseed.
flavour_note: Dried Fruit, Dates, Toffee, Malt, Honey, Raisins Rich and fruity, with black cherries, blackcurrants and redcurrants joined by nectarines. Dark chocolate and brown sugar follow, with hints of black liquorice and chocolate brownie. Thick, with a background of spice. Thick chocolate fudge cake emerges, studded with singed raisins and red-fruit jam. more savoury than expected from the nose. Long and warming, with black cherry, chocolate fudge and gentle aniseed.

name: Tomintoul 10 Year Old
reviews: Smooth and delicious || Possibly the best 10 y/o whisky I've come across. Sweet, malty and very smooth on the palate. Keith Earles circa 09 Lions Tour. || This single malt is lovely will definitely buy again x || a bit too spicy for me...but my friends love it. as with all whiskeys, preference is very subjective. || Depends on price. If priced above Glenmorangie 10, Glenlivet/Glenfiddich 12, Speyburn 10, Old Pulteney 12, then choose one of those. I got mine for way less, so I am happy. It's a simple, pleasant Speysider with not too much distillery character like Glenmorangie or Pulteney. Yet a pleasant clean malt with nice packaging.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Black Pepper, Honey, Toffee

name: Glenfarclas 21 Year Old
characters: Vanilla, Liquorice root, Brioche, Cinnamon, Dried Fruit, Apple
nose: Intense, full of aromas – sherried fruit, tropical fruit, nutmeg and almonds with slight citrus notes at the end, all held together with a vanilla sweet smokiness.
palate: Thick and sweet, with less complexity than the nose, zeroing in on brown sugar, stewed orange segments and lightly spiced syrup. A drop of water opened out the body a bit, softening the syrup hit and bringing out more fruit, with apples, apricots and blackcurrant leaves, as well as a bit more crunchy caramel sweetness.
finish: Long-lasting, smooth a smoky with a chocolate feel at the back of your throat.
reviews: This is some amazingly well made whiskey and it tastes incredible. This is my first time experiencing a whiskey aged 21 years. I’ll definitely get more of this and I’m looking forward to trying the 25 year as well! || This is a wonderful dram and actually very good value for money for a 21 year old. It's not one that will please all the sherry cask lovers, but it is beautifully refined and sweet in a different way. A nice smooth easy drinking dram with lots of character. Sweet to the nose. Oak, malt, dried fruit and a hint of chocolate on first taste. As it goes on, the fruit notes come through with hints of dried fruit tastes to the palate. The finish is what makes it worth it. You are left with that sweet satisfying taste that makes you want more... Another outstanding dram from Glenfarclas. Can't wait to try the 25yo. || Extremely smooth, warming and a deep rich flavour. I would highly recommend! || Utterly stunning || Really smooth, barley oaty taste with a hint of citrus & sweetness. I’m new to 21yr olds so not a lot to compare it to but loved it!
flavour_note: Vanilla, Liquorice root, Brioche, Cinnamon, Dried Fruit, Apple Intense, full of aromas – sherried fruit, tropical fruit, nutmeg and almonds with slight citrus notes at the end, all held together with a vanilla sweet smokiness. Thick and sweet, with less complexity than the nose, zeroing in on brown sugar, stewed orange segments and lightly spiced syrup. A drop of water opened out the body a bit, softening the syrup hit and bringing out more fruit, with apples, apricots and blackcurrant leaves, as well as a bit more crunchy caramel sweetness. Long-lasting, smooth a smoky with a chocolate feel at the back of your throat.

name: Benriach The Original Ten10 Year Old
characters: White Pepper, Ginger, Vanilla, Blackberry, Orange, Oak
reviews: Splendid dramming || Bit of a stealth mover, originally bought it as a low cost everyday dram but soon found myself going to it as a preference. Easy drinking but still satisfying, and a bargain at the price too. || A good Scotch whisky. Mild and round taste. Good taste after being aged in 3 different barrels during aging. || Really nice whisky. Added a drop of water to mine to suit my taste but perfectly drinkable straight. The tasting notes are bang on. Very nice bottle of whisky but I think I'll go for something slightly more smokey next time. Not that there's anything wrong with this one of course. || Very nice "mature" whisky for a 10 year old.
flavour_note: White Pepper, Ginger, Vanilla, Blackberry, Orange, Oak

name: Tamdhu 18 Year OldSherry Cask Matured
characters: Dried Fruit, Hazelnut, Milk Chocolate, Orange, Cinnamon, Nutmeg
reviews: On par with Macallan 18 for less than half the price. One of the best 18 year old Scotch.
flavour_note: Dried Fruit, Hazelnut, Milk Chocolate, Orange, Cinnamon, Nutmeg

name: Aultmore 201111 Year Old The Whisky Exchange
characters: Peach, Rhubarb, Vanilla, Clove, Mint, Toffee
nose: Buttery crumble topping with sharp rhubarb and softly sweet peaches are joined by crunchy barley sugar and boiled sweets: apple, pineapple and pear. Savoury brown butter and pastry notes build, balanced by sweet cream and dried apricot. Juicy stone fruit notes develop.
palate: Sweet, buttery pastry and sherbet lemons are balanced by gentle spice. Things continue with fresh and zingy fruit notes – sharp peach and apple – on one side and sweet grain the other – porridge and granola.
finish: Apple pie and buttery pasty with touches of chocolate at first. Aniseed and porridgey grain linger.
flavour_note: Peach, Rhubarb, Vanilla, Clove, Mint, Toffee Buttery crumble topping with sharp rhubarb and softly sweet peaches are joined by crunchy barley sugar and boiled sweets: apple, pineapple and pear. Savoury brown butter and pastry notes build, balanced by sweet cream and dried apricot. Juicy stone fruit notes develop. Sweet, buttery pastry and sherbet lemons are balanced by gentle spice. Things continue with fresh and zingy fruit notes – sharp peach and apple – on one side and sweet grain the other – porridge and granola. Apple pie and buttery pasty with touches of chocolate at first. Aniseed and porridgey grain linger.

name: Craigellachie 13 Year Old
nose: Big tropical-fruit aromas at first – mango and pineapple – followed by sweet and savoury notes of ham glazed with Demerara sugar and a whiff of barbecue smoke.
palate: More sweet fruit, tempered by savoury smokiness. Punchy and full-flavoured, with the meaty smoke balancing well with the refreshing tropical fruit. Mouth-filling texture; makes a statement!.
finish: The smoked-meat notes gently fade, along with a hint of spent match.
reviews: Sherry maturation instantly on the nose with some new shoe leather. An unusually robust, full flavoured dram for a Speyside which sets it apart. Tropical fruits early with the faintest hint of smoke on the finish. Delightful neat or with a drop of water. Waited a long time to have this in my collection. Thank you Maureen. || Love at first taste || Was so disappointed with this.It had been on my hitlist for ages and lo and behold I got a free sample.I know it's not a good premis for an opinion but it has made me pause and reflect.So many more out there to try!2.75/5 || Pour a fat dram, add a drop of water, and just leave it alone for a while. Let the matchstick subside (I love wormtubs!) with a rest in the glass. Enjoy. This whisky is fabulous. || Delicious!
flavour_note: Meat, Smoke, Mango, Pineapple, Matchbox Big tropical-fruit aromas at first – mango and pineapple – followed by sweet and savoury notes of ham glazed with Demerara sugar and a whiff of barbecue smoke. More sweet fruit, tempered by savoury smokiness. Punchy and full-flavoured, with the meaty smoke balancing well with the refreshing tropical fruit. Mouth-filling texture; makes a statement!. The smoked-meat notes gently fade, along with a hint of spent match.

name: Tomintoul 16 Year Old
nose: Soft fruits with hints of hazelnut and vanilla.
palate: Full flavour, nutty with spicy overtones.
finish: Creamy and velvety at first with, a spicy finish.
reviews: Smooth and tasty but nothing special for a 16 year old. || Lovely dram, got this on a trip to Scotland. Perfect description above, smooth. Hints of vanilla and nuts on the nose, sweet but not too sweet. Custard, slight orange peel, pear, a little spice perhaps hint of pepper here. Also get a tad toffee myself. Lovely drink well worth the money, paid a lot more for a lot less. Great value, superb drink. || A good value in non-peated whisky. Very smooth and gentle, its definitely a good choice for single malt novices. || A really nice smooth single malt at a good price. Recommend people try most tomintoul not had a bad one yet.. || A really gentle dram - vanilla, cinnamon - a smoooth single malt, value for money!!
flavour_note: Apple, Pear, Vanilla, Custard Soft fruits with hints of hazelnut and vanilla. Full flavour, nutty with spicy overtones. Creamy and velvety at first with, a spicy finish.

name: Glen Moray Port Cask FinishGlass Set
characters: Nutmeg, Cinnamon, Lemon, Dark Chocolate, Honey, Oak
reviews: I have only tasted the classic and the sherry cask, and they were both excellent, I would recommend Glen Moray to my friends. The port cask is a gift for friends visiting from America to take home with them.
flavour_note: Nutmeg, Cinnamon, Lemon, Dark Chocolate, Honey, Oak

name: Aberlour 12 Year Old Non Chill-Filtered
characters: Plums, Dark Chocolate, Toffee, Cinnamon, Raisins
nose: Rich and fruity with notes of sweet strawberry jam.
palate: Sherried character and deep fruity plum aromas balanced with rich chocolate, toffee, cinnamon and raisins.
finish: Long, sweet and very slightly spicy.
reviews: An excellent offering from Aberlour. I enjoy malt whisky in a whole range of styles, from smoky Islays to rich "sherry bombs" and all points between. But among the sweeter whiskies Aberlour has long been a firm favourite. While the flavours and aromas here are unmistakably Aberlour, the higher ABV and lack of filtration seem to slightly de-emphasise its inherent sweetness and allow significantly more complexity to show through. And though certainly not a "beginners' malt", the high ABV is very well integrated and never overly aggressive to drink neat (my own preference). All in all, while the core 12yo expression remains a favourite "easy-drinker", this is a whisky that thoroughly rewards more time and attention to savouring and is a real star turn in "bang for buck". This seems to no longer be available, and I REALLY hope that is only a temporary situation, as this is a whisky I would love to buy regularly in future as I'm sure others will too. || A tragically ignored gem of a whisky. Milk chocolate covered raisins, plums, toffee, sweet strawberries, spices and some dark chocolate oak to balance it out. All the other Aberlour expressions (except A'bunadh) are bottled at a paltry 40-43% ABV and I'm always left thinking how wonderful it would be if they had more presence, more power. With this dram I was not disappointed. Highly recommended! || Exceptional sherried whisky, more refined than the A’bunadh in my opinion and only surpassed by the magical Macallan Cask Strength || Very good,tasty dram this at a good 48%,so strong and full of flavour...well worth the reasonable price for the high quality you get!?? || Nice dram this one with caramel and vanilla..possibly hints of cinnamon.Good value for money..
flavour_note: Plums, Dark Chocolate, Toffee, Cinnamon, Raisins Rich and fruity with notes of sweet strawberry jam. Sherried character and deep fruity plum aromas balanced with rich chocolate, toffee, cinnamon and raisins. Long, sweet and very slightly spicy.

name: Glenlivet 12 Year Old Double Oak
palate: Flowery, peachy, notes of vanilla, delicate balance between sweetness & malty dryness.
reviews: Maybe it's my palate but I got a bitter or Bland flavor. No sweetness to be had. Brand new bottle, poured a bit over a cube of ice and a TINY splash of water. The warmth wasn't bad even nice feeling it travel all the way to my stomach and it was admittedly very smooth. I'm just not getting the flavors, notes etc that are described. || I'm more of an Irish Whiskey drinker but this is my go-to for Scotch Whisky...not too smokey. || Very smooth Scotch. Nice blended smoky flavour mixed with an essence of fruity notes. || It’s my absolute favorite drink, second to none. Great flavor, smooth and satisfying. || Scotch for beginner's, but it's a good entry into the scotch. Speyside whisky are usually are sweet and some have an floral testing with them.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Lemon, Toffee, Honeysuckle Remarkably flowery, clean & soft. Flowery, peachy, notes of vanilla, delicate balance between sweetness & malty dryness. Long, gently warming.

name: Dalwhinnie Distillers Edition
characters: Vanilla, Oak, Honey, Dried Fruit, Chestnut, Walnut
reviews: One of my favorites, always great
flavour_note: Vanilla, Oak, Honey, Dried Fruit, Chestnut, Walnut

name: Balvenie 21 Year OldPort Wood
characters: Cream, Cherry, Stewed Fruit, Honey, Raisins, Peach
nose: A perfume of fruity and ripe raisin notes, backed by a nutty dryness.
palate: A malt of refinement and remarkable character, it is creamy and silky with fruit, honey and spice notes, and has a long and gentle nutty finish.
finish: Long, with nuts and hints of cocoa.
reviews: Right up there as some of the finest whisky to pass my lips: a beautifully rounded, fruity flavour with a silky sweet finish…one for the top shelf || I first tried this whilst living in China where the Whisky scene has absolutely exploded, I love it! || I tried 14 excellent whiskies at a tasting last weekend. This one was the clear winner. It was the unanimous winner among myself and my six friends. Can't recommend it enough! || Love It || Finally got round to buying one of these. I wasn't disappointed! The port flavours are balanced and it doesn’t come across too sweet. Had to have a few glasses just to check but definitely a worthwhile addition to the whisky cupboard.
flavour_note: Cream, Cherry, Stewed Fruit, Honey, Raisins, Peach A perfume of fruity and ripe raisin notes, backed by a nutty dryness. A malt of refinement and remarkable character, it is creamy and silky with fruit, honey and spice notes, and has a long and gentle nutty finish. Long, with nuts and hints of cocoa.

name: Macallan Classic Cut 2023 Release
characters: Pear, Almond, Elderflower, Lemon, Wet wool (wet dog), Vanilla

name: Glen Moray 1998Barolo Finish Warehouse 1 Release
characters: Figs, Plums, Cream, Caramel, Milk Chocolate, Blackberry
reviews: I've just finished my first bottle of this stunning dram & luckily have another bottle left to enjoy. There's numerous flavours hitting your taste buds time and time again. It's a whisky to explore & savor, as those flavours come in waves & leave a satisfying finish. Even smelling the empty bottle is a pleasure in itself ! I think the price is par for the course at around £138 for a 23yr old bottled at 52.9% abv, non chill filtered, natural colour & only 853 bottles in total (what do folk expect). Buy & enjoy.......slowly || It’s ok, I get all the flavours as described. Definitely caramel chocolates. It’s a very ‘spiky’ though and for the price I would have preferred a much more ‘rounded’ effort. Yes the abv is up there but I was left feeling a little disappointed. At a cheaper price point I would have not felt that as it’s not a bad whisky and I did enjoy the barolo finish. || Nice, but fairly unremarkable and not worth the price in my opinion.
flavour_note: Figs, Plums, Cream, Caramel, Milk Chocolate, Blackberry

name: Glenfarclas 185th Anniversary
reviews: If you like Glen Farclas 15 yr old, then try this 185th Anniversary marriage of the pick of 6, I believe, selected casks from over the decades from the Glen Farclas' warehouses. It took the expertise of the Distillery Manager and the Managing Director to craft this special edition. For me with my ancient palate, its just sippers, slippers and a glowing log fire. I love it! || I've enjoyed this in September: more sherried and closer to Christmas than the 15 year old, greater fruit, but still as smooth as a (insert relevant inappropriate simile here)! Lovely. Expensive, but very good. If you like the 15, you'll enjoy this. Different from the 21 though, so beware.

characters: Butterscotch, Sponge cake, Stewed Fruit, Oak, Vanilla, Grapefruit

name: Tamdhu 12 Year OldSherry Cask Matured
characters: Cinnamon, Dried Fruit, Banana, Raspberry, Toffee, Mint
reviews: First of all on a technical point one of the nicest presented bottles going around. It’s a beautiful colour whisky and it’s sweet. Personally it has a slightly strong taste for a whisky of only %43 ABV when first drinking it comes on strong initially but the strong taste leaves fairly quickly. It’s overall a nice whisky. || I have to be honest I’m a big Tamdhu fan. I’ve enjoyed the 12, 15, and batch no. 4 and they are all incredible. The quality of the casks really does show. The 12 yo for the money is an absolutely beautifully crafted whisky made by people who really know their stuff. || A very nice smooth single malt to end the day with. || Doing wonderful things from sherry casks. Best 12 on the market! || This is a damn fine dram. Loved the 10, the 12 is fantastic, worth every penny. Very smooth to drink and can definitely pick up on the tablet taste!
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Dried Fruit, Banana, Raspberry, Toffee, Mint

name: Glen Grant 12 Year Old
finish: Lingering fruit with subtle hints of spice.
reviews: 4.75 || This whisky is simply delicious! It seems to fly under the radar...happily. || Clean, balanced and understated but with enough layers fruits, nuts and subtle spices to keep you coming back for more. Such a wonderful find, highly recommended. || The Emperor is fully dressed, aged and mellowed. The GG12 is a fantastic 12 yo, wonderful nose and smooth and fruity on the pallet and some spice hints on palate and tail. At first try, I found it more spicy, but after time it mellows. I love it, best 12 yo in my collection (over 20+ other 12's) beyond any doubt, and only go to it sparingly on a special evening (like a Macallan 12, not same in taste but in quality). If you can get it, don't hesitate. || OK, so Jim Murray has recently had the hots for Glen Grant. And yes, it is very smooth. And yes, there is lots of baked apple pie to it. But I think this is a bit of the "emperor's new clothes", as in "If JM loves it, I'll look smart by saying I love it too". But in truth, it's smoothness is only partly that subtlety that comes from superb craftsmanship; the other part is lack of individuality and character. Good, but not as great as advertised.
flavour_note: Apple, Cinnamon, Toffee, Vanilla, Leather Lingering fruit with subtle hints of spice.

name: Aberlour 16 Year Old Double Cask(43%)
nose: Creamy with sweet raisin aromas and a spicy nuttiness.
palate: A smooth blend of floral and spicy flavours, paired with a sweet plum fruitiness and gentle oakiness.
finish: Gloriously long, with a warm, honeyed spiciness.
reviews: Bought this whiskey after some research and it was sale at my local store. I love how smooth it is and I really enjoy the flavors. This is my first of it, I generally drink McCallan 12 yrs which isn't smooth this one. || Smooth and creamy, with subtle fruit taste. Highly recommended. || Sweet and good || One of my favourites. Not a huge difference from the 12 but just that little bit smoother and rounder. I like most of the Aberlours as they do not kick back but leave a warm and soft honeyed after taste. || Still available nowadays in France, I'd bought 2 bottles of this 43% version (bottling date : June 11, 2018). It's a real bargain. It's not that complex but with a drop or two of Vittel the aromas emphasise.
flavour_note: Creamy with sweet raisin aromas and a spicy nuttiness. A smooth blend of floral and spicy flavours, paired with a sweet plum fruitiness and gentle oakiness. Gloriously long, with a warm, honeyed spiciness.

name: Mortlach 16 Year OldDistiller's Dram
characters: Raisins, Apple, Clove, Dark Chocolate, Fruit Cake, Dates
nose: Rich and deep. It is slightly shy initially, but with a sense of massed weight. Stewed black and orchard fruits (damson, black cherry) with an immediate earthy note and some spice. While there is some honeyed sweetness, this has greater maturity than the 12-year-old, coming across as leaf mulch, with a burnt element: dried Nora pepper/grilled red pepper and light blackened skin (the pepper’s that is, not human) and chocolate which moves the meatiness towards molé. The oak is more relaxed (or integrated) allowing the gutsy almost feral weight of the distillate greater say but there is some planed wood alongside light varnish, then nutmeg and raisin. It gets progressively darker and richer with some biltong/beef jerky hints balanced by the sweetness. It also gets slightly nuttier, reminiscent of mature Gouda/Emmental.
palate: Big, quite deep, but also sweet. As on the nose, there’s some spiciness here (frying mustard seed). It is this sweeter element (toffee-like, with some dried apricot and the honey note seen on the nose) which comes over first. This softness then gives way to a chewy-mid palate where the darker fruits lurk. It then goes deep. Light, slightly leathery with malty elements then a gamey meatiness with supple tannins. However, rather than just the more powerful oak influence beginning to dominate the cooked fruits return adding a layered quality. Rather than sweetness you get a more savoury effect. Dark, full, liquorous, and rounded. As it moves into the back palate, so it starts to dry and pick up in terms of intensity and moves into the shadow of the trees.
finish: Surprisingly, it sweetens again. Long, complex and, yes, meaty. Now you also get the Syrah-like sootiness.
reviews:
I had purchased a couple of bottles of the 16-year-old Mortlach about12 years ago and I found it to be exceptional. That was the flora & fauna release. || Sherry, toffee, herbaceous on the nose. Caramel, salty, savoury, sticking plasters, straw, sour, lot’s going on. Bit full on alcohol hit but not burning. Finish is smooth and complex but overall savoury for me. || I just love it ! || Exceptional and exquisite whiskey.
Remain in your palate for long with different tastes and flavour 
Highly recommended || I've had this before,  its a damn good whisky, full flavoured and as they say...it is the beast of Dufftown.
I would prefer if it were non chill filtered and no caramel, just to see if it tastes any better but apart from that, i love my Mortlachs and always have.
flavour_note: Raisins, Apple, Clove, Dark Chocolate, Fruit Cake, Dates Rich and deep. It is slightly shy initially, but with a sense of massed weight. Stewed black and orchard fruits (damson, black cherry) with an immediate earthy note and some spice. While there is some honeyed sweetness, this has greater maturity than the 12-year-old, coming across as leaf mulch, with a burnt element: dried Nora pepper/grilled red pepper and light blackened skin (the pepper’s that is, not human) and chocolate which moves the meatiness towards molé. The oak is more relaxed (or integrated) allowing the gutsy almost feral weight of the distillate greater say but there is some planed wood alongside light varnish, then nutmeg and raisin. It gets progressively darker and richer with some biltong/beef jerky hints balanced by the sweetness. It also gets slightly nuttier, reminiscent of mature Gouda/Emmental. Big, quite deep, but also sweet. As on the nose, there’s some spiciness here (frying mustard seed). It is this sweeter element (toffee-like, with some dried apricot and the honey note seen on the nose) which comes over first. This softness then gives way to a chewy-mid palate where the darker fruits lurk. It then goes deep. Light, slightly leathery with malty elements then a gamey meatiness with supple tannins. However, rather than just the more powerful oak influence beginning to dominate the cooked fruits return adding a layered quality. Rather than sweetness you get a more savoury effect. Dark, full, liquorous, and rounded. As it moves into the back palate, so it starts to dry and pick up in terms of intensity and moves into the shadow of the trees. Surprisingly, it sweetens again. Long, complex and, yes, meaty. Now you also get the Syrah-like sootiness.

name: Glen Keith Distillery Edition
characters: Hay, Honey, Orange, Vanilla, Grass, Pear
reviews: A lovely easy drinkable whisky. Perfect to unwind with. || I received this single malt whisky from my granddaughter who lives in the South of England as I do and knowing that I am originally from Banffshire she thought I would appreciate it,well I certainly did! This is an excellent well rounded mature palate with an excellent aftertaste,well done I am no expert but when something is correct it has to be applauded . I digress,I wonder if Sheila Steele still lives in Keith. || This is my favourite easy-drinking whisky. Not overpowering, smooth and fresh tasting. A glass at the end of the day is always something to look forward to. || Deliciously smooth with vanilla, toffee and ripe orchard fruit overtones . || Very easy drinking and incredible value.
flavour_note: Hay, Honey, Orange, Vanilla, Grass, Pear

name: A Good Old-Fashioned Christmas Whisky 15 Year Old2024 Edition
characters: Fruit Cake, Sherry, Orange, Milk Chocolate, Dried Fruit, Nutmeg
reviews: Third year of having it great again || Bought this as a stocking filler for my husband and he throughly enjoyed it. Calls it Christmas in a bottle! || Almonds, cherry, chocolate, and fruitcake, big sherry bomb, pulls up a bit short, but it's lovely. Worth the price. Better than 2023. || Oh what a glorious whisky. If sherry is your jam, then get this now. A fabulous speysider and so easy to sip even at this strength. Come on Billy/Dawn...tell us which distillery this is please! || I thought I’d try a bottle to see what it was like. I liked it so much, I bought two more…one for me and my friends, and one as a gift for my bestie. It’s very Speyside in character, with subtle spicy notes that make it a lovely holiday whisky.
flavour_note: Fruit Cake, Sherry, Orange, Milk Chocolate, Dried Fruit, Nutmeg

name: Glen Moray Sherry Cask Finish
characters: Dark Chocolate, Vanilla, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Toffee, Orange
nose: Bursting with dried fruits, cinnamon and toffee candy.
finish: Satisfyingly long with a tingle of spice.
reviews: This is a beautiful whiskey one you could expect to pay more for. I will definitely be buyer more. Thank you || Definitely better than the monkey shoulder at same price. || Really, really good. Just enough bite to be interesting, complex flavors. It's hard to believe you can pick up something this interesting and smooth for less than $30. || Absolutely delightful hit of sweet dried fruit, lightly spiced. Smooth. Priced well below its value, for sure. || Probably the best NAS from this distillery. Very sweet, almost chewable, with the sherry influence dominating. Good value easy drinking whisky which is lightly spiced which I prefer.
flavour_note: Dark Chocolate, Vanilla, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Toffee, Orange Bursting with dried fruits, cinnamon and toffee candy. Satisfyingly long with a tingle of spice.

name: Cragganmore 2007 Distillers EditionBot.2019
characters: Raspberry, Honey, Tobacco, Stewed Fruit, Oak
food_paring: Red Wine Sauce, Cherry Pie, Salmon Roasted
reviews: A very smooth whisky. There is next to no bite and is sweet. Tasting notes above are accurate.
flavour_note: Raspberry, Honey, Tobacco, Stewed Fruit, Oak

name: Knockando 12 Year Old
characters: Milk Chocolate, Brioche, Sultana, Cinnamon, Black Pepper, Banana
reviews: I know this is hard scotch to find as a single malt as the majority of it goes into blends. It's a nice scotch it's sweet and pleasant but still has a strong kick at the end for a malt that's only %43 ABV I certainly wouldn't dismiss it has something that I would never drink again but I can think of several other 12 year old single malts that I think are superior and same around the same price level || In my opinion, this is the best whisky on the market. So pleased I've now found a place I can buy it. Generally very difficult to find. || I’m not a scotch sniffer, but a scotch drinker. The BEST I’ve ever had., hands down. || I bought Knockando 40 years ago, when our store happened to stock it! Now, years later could not find it anywhere, until I went on line and found The Whiskey Exchange!!! Thank you so much, everything was great, my order came promptly, and it is like running into an old friend!! Thank you, Thank you!
flavour_note: Milk Chocolate, Brioche, Sultana, Cinnamon, Black Pepper, Banana

name: Speyburn 15 Year Old
nose: Hints of rich dark chocolate with spicy notes of raisins, zesty citrus fruits and vanilla.
reviews: At 46% natural colour and unchill filtered makes this a great option IMO. The tasting notes are spot on, this is a very nice dram to spend a bit of time with. I can't decide whether to re order or try the 18 yr next. || Smooth and soft, a touch of chocolate and a short, soft, spicy finish. || Having tried a taster bottle of this, I have to agree with the people that gave it a silver medal at the International Wine & Spirits Competition 2017. It is a lovely dram, that hits all the notes it claims. It reminded sort of me of a more refined and complex Glenfiddich 15 Year Old Solera. However, I find it hard to justify an extra ?20 for this extra flavor over the Glenfiddich 15 Year Old Solera. You get a dram almost as nice for almost 1/2 the price. If money is of no concern then get the Speyburn it IS nicer. No question a well deserved silver medal winner, but if you can't push the boat of for it then the Glenfiddich 15 Year Old Solera is a good substitute / budget equivalent.
flavour_note: Apple, Vanilla, Orange, Liquorice root Hints of rich dark chocolate with spicy notes of raisins, zesty citrus fruits and vanilla.

name: Glenfiddich Project XXExperimental Series
characters: Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Apple, Orange, Hazelnut, Biscuits
nose: Barley sugar and lardy cake are followed by dry cinnamon and nutmeg notes. Then things get juicy, with pine needles, freshly peeled orange zest, lime jelly and hints of Haribo. Water adds in layers of fruity toffee.
palate: Chocolate-covered caramels, black pepper, orange cream and singed orange peel lead things, with milk-chocolate truffles and hazelnuts bringing up the rear. Water reveals the toffee from the nose on the palate as well as adding sweet stewed apples and sharp Granny Smiths.
finish: Dry and softly spicy to start, with sweet hints of digestive and shortbread biscuits building with butter and spice.
reviews: Some nice plop. Great work chaps || Standard Glenfiddich whiskey. Not the best one nor the worst. Alcohol content to strong. Fire @ Cane more enjoyable || Not my favourite whisky from the Glenfiddich range but pleasant enough. First taste isn’t the best but once you’ve had a few sips it grows on you. || Not a Glenfiddich fan, however the oakiness has been replaced with a sweet spicy backbone which resembles the glendronach 12 mixed with redbreast's lustau. This is one to try for the discerning sweet tooth drinker. At 47% this is incredibly drinkable and has a resemblance to more expensive whiskies such as glenmorangie signet or glenfarclas 105. || Can’t believe that I’m the first to review this phenomenal masterpiece! Smooth and sweet with candy floss, chocolate, etc. , complemented well by nuttiness and orange. It is as good as many 150-200? whiskies I’ve seen. Something you must try!
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Apple, Orange, Hazelnut, Biscuits Barley sugar and lardy cake are followed by dry cinnamon and nutmeg notes. Then things get juicy, with pine needles, freshly peeled orange zest, lime jelly and hints of Haribo. Water adds in layers of fruity toffee. Chocolate-covered caramels, black pepper, orange cream and singed orange peel lead things, with milk-chocolate truffles and hazelnuts bringing up the rear. Water reveals the toffee from the nose on the palate as well as adding sweet stewed apples and sharp Granny Smiths. Dry and softly spicy to start, with sweet hints of digestive and shortbread biscuits building with butter and spice.

name: Inchgower 200713 Year Old Bourbon Cask Artful Dodger
characters: Custard, Ginger, Mango, Coconut, Honey, Oats
flavour_note: Custard, Ginger, Mango, Coconut, Honey, Oats

name: Glenfiddich Orchard ExperimentExperimental Series #05
reviews: In my opinion, an excellent addition to the Glenfiddich range of whiskies. A smooth whisky with an orchard fruit aftertaste. || Has a lovely spice, vibrant edge to it, easy to drink with a distinctive body. Light but also carries depth, best Glenfiddich I’ve had so far. || I have had four bottles of this, the first divine. Like it so much I got another three, but all three have the perfumes pot pouri that another reviewer was talking about. I didn’t get those three from TWE (just to be clear). A puzzling experience. || The nicest Glenfiddich yet! Fresh, appley and vibrant a totally unique taste. I've shared this with friends and they've bought their own bottles now. Get it whilst you can || Really grim! I’m up for experimental whiskies and have enjoyed many fine bottles that have been finished in various barrels (including sherry, oak, red wine and so on) but this tastes like it’s been mixed with pot pourri - and most of the pot pourri has been left in. Artificial tasting and just undrinkable. Only the second bottle of whiskey ever that I’ll be pouring straight down the sink!
flavour_note: Apple, Vanilla, Oak, Caramel

name: Benromach 15 Year Old
characters: Milk Chocolate, Fruit Cake, Ginger, Apple, Mint, Honey
nose: Chocolate, caramel and wood smoke lead to a hint of new-trainer-sole rubber and rich maltiness – Shreddies cereal and malt extract. The smokiness winds its way through the gaps, becoming wispy coal smoke trickling out of a stove filled with baking sultana-studded apples.
palate: Rich, thick and rounded, with sultanas and raisins quickly overwhelmed by spicy peat smoke. The baked apples from the nose are revealed as the smoke blows away, sprinkled with spicy cinnamon and mint leaves. Chocolate-covered liquorice and Hob Nob biscuits appear, along with a touch of charcoal.
finish: Singed fruit cake and sultana-heavy fruit loaf fade slowly away to leave tingling menthol, leafy mint and cocoa.
reviews: Splendid dram, rich fruit,lightly spiced with a hint of smoke.a good winter warmer || Has loads of character. Hint of peat on the nose and strong oak flavours but remains smooth. Has spice and bite. Cereal notes are strong. Quite a dry finish. Good. || Cannot try the product, because it is a X-mas present to some one (who may be able to comment at a later date !). But as I have seen many "old" whiskies it is one of the good products, otherwise it would not have been voted Whisky of the year. || Not my thing. Just did not impress. I had a mouthful of whisky which is about the end of it. || Excellent :)
flavour_note: Milk Chocolate, Fruit Cake, Ginger, Apple, Mint, Honey Chocolate, caramel and wood smoke lead to a hint of new-trainer-sole rubber and rich maltiness – Shreddies cereal and malt extract. The smokiness winds its way through the gaps, becoming wispy coal smoke trickling out of a stove filled with baking sultana-studded apples. Rich, thick and rounded, with sultanas and raisins quickly overwhelmed by spicy peat smoke. The baked apples from the nose are revealed as the smoke blows away, sprinkled with spicy cinnamon and mint leaves. Chocolate-covered liquorice and Hob Nob biscuits appear, along with a touch of charcoal. Singed fruit cake and sultana-heavy fruit loaf fade slowly away to leave tingling menthol, leafy mint and cocoa.

name: Glenallachie 8 Year Old
characters: Honey, Ginger, Biscuits, Heather, Cinnamon, Milk Chocolate
reviews: Nice whisky. || Good entry to GA range, and value for money. However very sweet and syrupy in comparison to the much better 15 yr old and 10 yr cask strength that I adore. Even sweeter than the 11PX and lacks the complexity of these other expressions. My view - great if you’re on a budget, but the older albeit more expensive Glenallachie bottles are much better. I was left craving a Campbeltown to balance the sugar overload after tasting.
flavour_note: Honey, Ginger, Biscuits, Heather, Cinnamon, Milk Chocolate

name: Singleton of Dufftown 15 Year Old
reviews: Recently i bought this whisky. My first impression the smell, it reminds me of spring autumm weather. I like the taste. The best way to try it is have it neat. I like the colour of the bottle, value for money. || II found this whisky and bought it partly because of the great price, partly because of the of the great reviews I read. Initially, I didn't like it. The first two drams were OK, but nothing else. I just tried it last week, after five moths of "forgetting about it" and it was just great. I don't know what happened, it 's just so much better now. || On the nose and palate its very sweet, for me there's an overwhelming taste of apples and more specifically the finish is a mouthful of peeled green apple skin. Overall, it's a good whisky but it's incredibly mild and not long lasting on the finish. || this is one of the smoothies scotch whisky i've ever tasted and i've tasted many over the years of traveling in scotland || Great whisky, a bit heavier than the twelve years old one

Quite enjoyable. || Got this bottle for my b-day from my best friend. Really enjoyed its sweet smell and sweet finish. great whisky for this price! || My first taste of this when a bottle was all alone on the self in sainsburys reduced to clear for £19-99p discontinued line.one of nicest malts i have tasted still looking out for any more bottles which may be out their.

name: Glen Grant 10 Year Old
nose: Orange and lemon zest, vanilla cream and toffee.
palate: Oily, with fudge and cream chased by orange, lemon, honeysuckle and sweet apple.
finish: Freshly crushed grain, soft apple and a hint of peach.
reviews: Excellent. Tastes like an 18 year old Scotch. || Unparalleled || I don’t really understand unless it’s just me how many impressive reviews there are about this whisky. Personally I don’t think it’s anything special. Nice Colour and reasonably sweet but it’s got no lasting finish and it’s not the kind of 10 year old or maybe even a 12 year old that makes you feel after you have drunk it that says wow I must buy it again and have a stock of it regularly. I can think of at least 4 other 10 year olds and at least another 4 12 year olds almost the same price or very close in the Ballpark that are far superior to this whisky || Excellent whisky. Beautifully made, notes of ginger and melon on the nose. Light in style but plenty of spice. This is top rate. || This is a rather marvellous drop. Smooth and warming, perfect for a one-off to relax or to keep going for a few more to bring further joy! I looked on this site for a long time before choosing this one and I'm glad I made the right choice. Highly recommended.
flavour_note: Orange, Lemon, Cream, Toffee, Honeysuckle Orange and lemon zest, vanilla cream and toffee. Oily, with fudge and cream chased by orange, lemon, honeysuckle and sweet apple. Freshly crushed grain, soft apple and a hint of peach.

name: Allt-a-Bhainne 200021 Year Old Sherry Cask Signatory
Craigellachie 17 Year Old
characters: Dried Fruit, Pineapple, Vanilla, Malt, Oak, Liquorice root
reviews: Well balanced and tasty. A surprise. || This is a surprise and a joy. The Craigellachie spirit is often too sulfury for my tastes, but this is an amazingly balanced, and well-crafted dram. The cask balance is perfect, a mixture of malt and sweet and spice... it is not dominated by any, but luxurious in each. It blows away the 13 year and I only wish my bottle was more full. The nose is a spectrum of fruits with a hint of oak, but on the palate the oak is glorious and mostly manifest as spices from the kitchen... a hint of ginger and curry, peaches and plums, cinnamon toast, a bit of coconut and maple syrup... and a gushing backbone of maltiness. Way too drinkable... || Rarely have I been privileged to try such a stunning, yet balanced dram. Craigellachie is often to sulfury for me, yet this whisky is divine, and balanced so well as to be nearly indecipherable. The heart of the whisky is a perfect balance of sherry and bourbon casks, sweet and spicy, with only a hint of ancient wood. Fruits and winter spices, but sung throughout with strong barley and breakfast breads... more, please. I feel lucky. || Very impressed, very smooth and I enjoy the touch of sweetness. And a tad bit of smoke..very easy to drink , no burn. Very good , if u enjoy Hibiki, or Monkey Shoulder's, this is far superior. || A splendid taste with a warm feel to it. Not to smoky but silky smooth.
flavour_note: Dried Fruit, Pineapple, Vanilla, Malt, Oak, Liquorice root

You will definitely enjoy it!

name: Caperdonich 200021 Year Old Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cherry, Almond, Vanilla, Fruit Cake, Pear, Toffee
nose: Cherry Bakewells – vanilla custard, hints of light fruit cake and a touch of orgeat almond. Fruity notes build: apple sauce with sultanas, spice and a touch of banana.
palate: Creamy toffee and caramel leading to spiced apple and fruit cake. The cherry and almond notes from the nose reappear along with singed raisins and custard. Polished oak and lardy cake notes poke out the sides. Fresh apple and roasted pears with a touch of sharp white grape.
finish: Creamy spiced apple and cream notes slowly.
reviews: I really enjoy hibiki masters blend available only from duty free . But this was something else. I am going to purchase another bottle to keep for a few years. The subtle fruit cake and citrus flavours that came through really mixed well with my cigar choice and light chocolate to accompany it. || Seemed almost a bit of smoke or pear . Sweet. Full bodied. Sophisticated. Enjoyable. And a bit different. Orange. Smooth.
flavour_note: Cherry, Almond, Vanilla, Fruit Cake, Pear, Toffee Cherry Bakewells – vanilla custard, hints of light fruit cake and a touch of orgeat almond. Fruity notes build: apple sauce with sultanas, spice and a touch of banana. Creamy toffee and caramel leading to spiced apple and fruit cake. The cherry and almond notes from the nose reappear along with singed raisins and custard. Polished oak and lardy cake notes poke out the sides. Fresh apple and roasted pears with a touch of sharp white grape. Creamy spiced apple and cream notes slowly.

name: Glenfiddich Fire and CaneExperimental Series #04
characters: Orange, Toffee, Cinnamon, Oak, Apple, Smoke
nose: Billowing soft peat notes, like distant smoke on the wind. Rich sweet toffee and zesty fresh fruit notes and spiciness.
palate: Like a Highland peat campfire, with oak notes and toffee. Sharp green fruit, sweet baked apples and soft smoke.
reviews: Itvwas purchased for my 60th birthday. What a delight. Its smooth very tasty and didnt last long in the bottle. For a single malt whisky its way up there. || I was a bit sceptical at first to buy this but boy am I happy I did. This has quickly become my favourite scotch. It's very different and unique. Taste wise it's not something you will find with other scotches. The smokiness comes through more here than anything else I've tried. It's sweet but it isn't overpowering. It goes down smooth and doesn't have much of a bite. If you don't like smoky then this isn't a scotch for you but that balance between sweet and smoky makes every sip its own journey. Amazing. || My favorite whisky. It's so good, and the smell is so great- i kept the bottle just to smell it after i finished the bottle. || Just received my bottle today, it has a nice smokey taste with an undertone which I find reminiscent of saffron. I'm no connoisseur but believe it's a nice whiskey. || Certainly interesting but neither the peat nor the rum finish really stands out in an exceptional way. The flavors aren't anything that can't be found in cheaper scotches. It's not bad, just nothing special. Which for the price warrants the 3 stars.
flavour_note: Orange, Toffee, Cinnamon, Oak, Apple, Smoke Billowing soft peat notes, like distant smoke on the wind. Rich sweet toffee and zesty fresh fruit notes and spiciness. Like a Highland peat campfire, with oak notes and toffee. Sharp green fruit, sweet baked apples and soft smoke. Lingering smokiness and sweetness.

finish: Boozy apple crumble, with cinnamon and milk chocolate.
reviews: An easy-drinking scotch – smooth and enjoyable. || Haven’t tried the product! It’s a Christmas present! However, I do know that the recipient loves Macallan whisky! I loved the standard of the engraving. Thank you. || Smooth, easy drinking || An excellent scotch. Very clean, smooth sweet with a little heat. One of the best for under 80$(CAD) || Quite a different type of character. Definitely not as good as the 12 or 15 year. I'm not getting much of the fruit that others write about. Almost getting bit of brine and salt water. Had high hopes based on other reviews but this one is not for me.
flavour_note: Grape, Milk Chocolate, Raisins, Toast, Cinnamon Pain aux raisins and brioche, with some cleansing grapey notes and toasty spice. Cinnamon and boozy raisins. Rich texture, mouthfilling, but still precise and clean. Easy to drink. Boozy apple crumble, with cinnamon and milk chocolate.

name: Mortlach 12 Year OldThe Wee Witchie
characters: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Walnut, Dates, Lemon
nose: Rich and deep, with immediate warming, toasty oak tones (wood shavings) and a light peachy element that moves towards honey and then cooked fruits hinting at good depth. Some chestnut helps to add a sweet nutty background alongside hints of wax crayon. This impression of oak, sandalwood, light spice, and fruit - now with some dried berries - slowly gives way to some charred elements, hard (Highland) toffee and some light meatiness. Once this is established (and it takes time) it starts to deepen, earthy, petrichor, (the smell of early autumn), dried blossom, pineapple and bitter orange that itself extends into Terry’s chocolate orange and then cooked plum. As it dries so the woodland gives way to a coal bunker/lichen encrusted logs in a woodpile.
palate: A sweet, almost peachy, concentrated start with a little oak and almost smoky (charred) element. It’s at its most expressive on the mid-palate where you pick out bitter chocolate, marmalade and light tobacco that’s balanced by a puddle of syrup before it deepens further and starts to grip, there’s liquorice, roast chestnut, tree bark, roasting coffee, and a burnt edge which might be the sulphur working its way out. As it develops so you get bourbon biscuit, then the meaty flavours which themselves have the herbal qualities of goat or lamb. The grip loosens, and light gets back in with things getting sweeter and also more spicy.
finish: Quite dry and slightly sooty/ashy with oak (fresh-sawn timber). There’s some plum with an added hint of bitterness.
reviews: Good autumn dram. || Fabulous 12yo from Speyside. Not sure I need to try older expressions from this distillery. The 'Wee Witchie' is as good as anything I've sampled from the region. There's creamy toffee, and a hint of liquorice along with the alcohol on the nose. It's Christmas cake in a glass on the palate as sherried fruits and nuts come through, with a lovely dry finish. One that I'll always have in the collection. One criticism, poor quality cheap plastic seal and poor fitting cork, caused slight leakage on my bottle. Retailer changed without question but something distillery needs to look at. Far too good a product to scrimp on poor quality seal. || Loved it. Smooth with a little burn at the end. Both me and my father enjoyed it. || Mortlach 12 is delicious! Not a spicy dram, but nutty and fruity. Give it a long rest in the glass (20 minutes) and no water. Simply superb. || This is a shockingly good whisky. One of the best I've had. I can't even discard the empty bottle .It too is a good thing.
flavour_note: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Walnut, Dates, Lemon Rich and deep, with immediate warming, toasty oak tones (wood shavings) and a light peachy element that moves towards honey and then cooked fruits hinting at good depth. Some chestnut helps to add a sweet nutty background alongside hints of wax crayon. This impression of oak, sandalwood, light spice, and fruit - now with some dried berries - slowly gives way to some charred elements, hard (Highland) toffee and some light meatiness. Once this is established (and it takes time) it starts to deepen, earthy, petrichor, (the smell of early autumn), dried blossom, pineapple and bitter orange that itself extends into Terry’s chocolate orange and then cooked plum. As it dries so the woodland gives way to a coal bunker/lichen encrusted logs in a woodpile. A sweet, almost peachy, concentrated start with a little oak and almost smoky (charred) element. It’s at its most expressive on the mid-palate where you pick out bitter chocolate, marmalade and light tobacco that’s balanced by a puddle of syrup before it deepens further and starts to grip, there’s liquorice, roast chestnut, tree bark, roasting coffee, and a burnt edge which might be the sulphur working its way out. As it develops so you get bourbon biscuit, then the meaty flavours which themselves have the herbal qualities of goat or lamb. The grip loosens, and light gets back in with things getting sweeter and also more spicy. Quite dry and slightly sooty/ashy with oak (fresh-sawn timber). There’s some plum with an added hint of bitterness.

name: Loch Dhu 10 Year Old
reviews: They claimed it got its colour from the casks it was matured in, that was false,the "bhu"was added by caramel before bottling which led to its being withdrawn making its new rarity collectable.it was a shame really because loch bhu was an excellent dram to be sipped neat as it did not appreciate the addition of any water || Yes,twice and found Loch Dhu the most delightfull whisky ever sampled. || Silky smooth and viscous. EXCELLENT! As best my unsophisticated pallet could tell, licorice, tar, earth, caramel. Looks a bit like old, crankcase oil. 1st taste, given a 1/2 litre. Bought 1 full and 1/2 litre online. Bought a Japanese packaged bottle on Ebay! Now that I've found you, I'll be ordering more! || Peat meets treacle and Guinness, silky smooth and viscous . Superb! || guinness, liquorice, tar, chocolate, earth, treacle, caramel on the (short) finish. interesting but not really worth the price of admission.

name: Old Ballantruan
nose: Citrussy, very aromatic. A distant dry smokiness swirling up. A mineral touch (wet pebble). Then a fruity whiff of ripe peaches and pears. All is wrapped in a delicate honeyed veil.
palate: Rich, silky, enticing. Oily, getting drier on the tongue as spices burst out. Some green gage flavours mingling with spices.
reviews: I purchased a bottle at the highland games in Pitlochry after having a "wee dram". I'm not one for peated scotch, but the Old Ballantruan won me over at first sip. I brougha bottlet back to the US to share with friends. It's a beautiful whiskey. || A cracking speyside peaty whisky. I would rate 3 on smoke rather 2. I am a major fan of islay smokey whisky and this one is a definite in the drinks collection! || Tastes great smoke and flavor notes harmonize perfectly. a very delicious smoked whiskey. One of my top smoked whiskeys || I found this to be quite spectacular for the price. The tasting notes are spot on. || Rough with too much caramel and far too pricey for what it is, given that I can buy Laphroaig 10 and Ardbeg 10 cheaper than this.
flavour_note: Smoke, Malt, Praline, Lemon, Hazelnut Citrussy, very aromatic. A distant dry smokiness swirling up. A mineral touch (wet pebble). Then a fruity whiff of ripe peaches and pears. All is wrapped in a delicate honeyed veil. Rich, silky, enticing. Oily, getting drier on the tongue as spices burst out. Some green gage flavours mingling with spices. Lemony, drying on ginger.

name: Glenfiddich 1991Don Ramsay Bot.2004
reviews: About as good a whisky as glenfiddich has ever produced. I wish I had bought them all off the shelf when they were 20 quid in asda, Elgin when they were first released. £150 is a lot, but trust me its worth it.

finish: Long with highlights of chocolate and stewed fruit finishing with lingering winter spices.
reviews: Great whisky. The fruit notes and sweetness are well balanced. Really a fan of the Discovery Range by Gordon & MacPhail. || Bought for my father and he loved it. Milton Duff is his favourite malt and hard to get these days. This bottle from the sherry cask he really enjoyed and felt it brought something extra to his favourite whisky. || I opened this last evening to give myself a change from Islay and Campbeltown drams and really enjoyed the sherry character of this Miltonduff. the tasting notes above are pretty spot-on - there's plenty of fruit and spice and it is a rich whisky. the only thing I'd add is that I got a bit of a perfumy dryness on the finish, which was very pleasant. Four stars because I prefer whiskies to be at least 46% and non-chillfiltered. || Nice, sweet and spice with pleasant, mouth-coating textures.
flavour_note: Dark Chocolate, Marmalade, Raisins, Apple, Grass, Cinnamon Long with highlights of chocolate and stewed fruit finishing with lingering winter spices.

name: Balvenie 16 Year Old French OakPineau Cask Finish
characters: Apple, Grapefruit, Honey, Ginger, Geranium, Grass
nose: Beautifully balanced light floral notes from lotus and geranium flowers dance between hints of fresh meadow grass and peeled apple skin.
palate: A energizing zing from tangy lemon rind and grapefruit meet the delicate subtle sweetness of glazed fruits and spice from root ginger.
reviews: Perhaps a price range of £70-90 would help it! || At first I thought I had erred in my purchase but after several months I came back to it. I was surprised at how much I began to enjoy it. It certainly has been a nice change from the sherry based malts I have been drinking from Glendronach, Hazelburn and Dalmore. It is a solid bottling from Balvenie and I am glad for my purchase. || Great addition to any French oak whisky lovers profile. The nose here excels far past the palate and finish but all three are very well balanced with the wine influence from the wood. Sampled these with 2 other French oak finished bourbons and this one took first!!
flavour_note: Apple, Grapefruit, Honey, Ginger, Geranium, Grass Beautifully balanced light floral notes from lotus and geranium flowers dance between hints of fresh meadow grass and peeled apple skin. A energizing zing from tangy lemon rind and grapefruit meet the delicate subtle sweetness of glazed fruits and spice from root ginger. Refreshingly concise.

name: Tomintoul Seiridh
characters: Figs, Christmas Cake, Dried Fruit, Milk Chocolate, Cinnamon, Butterscotch
reviews: Tomintoul Seridh (sherry) - not much sherry influence to the eye, on the nose or to taste but, that said, this is a decent version of Tomintoul at a fair price. A Glendronach it is not but it is a sherry finish for a few months rather than having been matured for the whole time in sherry casks. It is a very smooth, fruity whisky with a long sweet finish and I must say that I have enjoyed every dram so far.
flavour_note: Figs, Christmas Cake, Dried Fruit, Milk Chocolate, Cinnamon, Butterscotch

name: Glenallachie Distillery Edition
reviews: This is not quite as smooth as the writing on the box claims, however that said it is a really flavoursome malt and delicious when chilled with ice || Got two bottles of this lovely whiskey on offer half price – £15 each – and thought at that price would try it. Would I have paid full price? Probably; for a single malt it ticks most of the boxes. It’s smooth with a nice warmth that doesn’t overpower. It’s not peaty which is good for me as I don’t like the overly peated (almost dental) taste in some whiskies. It’s on par with Glen Keith or lower-end Jura. If you want a whisky to impress but don’t want to blow your budget, give it a whirl – your guest/recipient won’t be disappointed. || Yes have tried this whisky, it is a lovely dram and is very mild . || Have also tried this and agree with the young age part of previous review.I personally think this is about 8 years old at most and it shows in how spirity it is on the nose.I cant find a lot to say about this , apart from along with the Glen Keith of the same packaging it is a very poor offering from Pernod Ricard for both distilleries.I have said of the Glen Keith bottling that an expression of 10-12 years and 46 abv could showcase both distilleries in a better light. || Amazing how a distillery so close to Aberlour can come up with something so different. It has notes of rhubarb, baked apple, custard, flapjack, vanilla, gooseberry and sherbert. No age statement but it does not feel under-matured - maybe 10 years old or so. Yes it is off the radar a bit but worth buying for something made in vast quantities yet retaining distinctive flavours.

name: Aberlour A'Bunadh Batch 57
reviews:
My single favorite bottle, and one I am never without. The variance in flavor between batches is noticeable and welcome - variations on a theme.  This requires a little patience to open up, but is very rewarding once it does. If you are looking to expand your horizons or are new to this kind of brown water, this is an excellent place to start. || Great whisky, has an excellent taste. Highly recomended! One of my favourites. || Id heard alot of good things about abunadh and so was very interested in trying it. I have to admit at first i was quite disappointed, yes there were some lovely rich flavours but all rather mute. I tried it neat and with a little water and both times with around 20 minutes in the glass before tasting. I cannot claim to be an expert by any stretch of the imagination but i expected a greater experience from this whisky (batch 57 ) 

Now a month on with a quater of the bottle gone my opinion has changed. Its a lovely dram, one that i expected it to be. I think the oxidisation has really helped this bottle open up. I highly recommend it, but definitely needs a bit of time and air. || This is a great bottle, the taste is powerfull and i personaly tryed straight and with water and i prefer straight ! The nose the taste and the after tase are givin you all what you was looking for , but for the price go with the aberloir 12! Dont esitate for the powerfull ! || Got my first bottle last month! Fantastic sherried style whisky from aberlour. Definitely needs a little water to take off the burn from 60% but the flavours are so good, Christmas cake, cherrys, chocolate.. so so good just grab a bottle and enjoy!

name: Glenrothes 199018 Year Old Sherry Cask Single Malts of Scotland
Cragganmore 12 Year OldSmall Bottle
nose: An aromatic blast of citrus to begin with – orange and lemon oil – then soft aromas of toffee, roasted almonds and malted biscuits follow. Very clean and appetising, with a gentle floral character.
palate: The fresh citrus notes continue on to the palate, joined by sweet toffee, malt and oat biscuits. Very clean and refreshing.
reviews: Lovely! Says it all. But so easy to drink I have to pace myself! Definitely a must try! || Very fruity, delicate, vivid and vibrant single malt Scotch whisky. Full of character, reveals its personality in every sip both on the nose and palate. Certainly more feminine than masculine, and perfect Scotch for spring/summer days. It should also be noted here that my lady friends with a taste for Scotch claim Cragganmore 12 Year to be their most favorite Scotch for all the reasons listed above. Enjoy!
flavour_note: Orange, Lemon, Almond, Biscuits, Toffee An aromatic blast of citrus to begin with – orange and lemon oil – then soft aromas of toffee, roasted almonds and malted biscuits follow. Very clean and appetising, with a gentle floral character. The fresh citrus notes continue on to the palate, joined by sweet toffee, malt and oat biscuits. Very clean and refreshing. The gentle maltiness fades lightly.

reviews: Silky smooth and quite mellow with just enough flavor and finish to justify its very reasonable price which could quite easily tempt any Speysider fan to forsake their uusual tipple simply out of curiosity and those that do.... May well be glad they did ! Ladies will love this- Sweet delicate and moreish dram.
flavour_note: Toffee, Vanilla, White Pepper, Nutmeg, Mint, Lemon

name: Glenlivet Founder's Reserve
nose: Delicate aromas of citrus fruit, notably sweet orange.
palate: Sweet, fruit notes of zesty oranges and pears, with a hint of candy, toffee apples. Well-balanced and exceptionally smooth.
reviews: When an established distillery fills a whiskey into a really nice (!) flask, names it "Founder's Reserve", people would expect a matching quality. This drink does not meet those expectations at all. Raw, scratchy, metallic. The potential is there, but would have needed much more ageing. Overpositioning a product like this, and misleading customers by doing so will alienate fans from this otherwise quite palatable brand. Sorry. || Lovely,smooth tasty,warming. || 3.5. Pleasant dram. Nothing overpowering. You can tell there is some young liquid in here particularly on the nose which carries a little too much alcohol. As with many NAS drams, improves with resting and maybe a bit of ice (shock horror!). Hilarious reading these reviews though. My favourite comments are: - "a good starting whisky", subtly boasting that the reviewer is a seasoned veteran with a highly tuned palate, more used to complex flavours - "there are better blends out there", well yeah... there are some incredible blends out there. - "tastes watered down", well yeah!...its bottled at 40% which means the distillery almost certainly (as with any 40% bottling) added purified water when bottling... watering it down. While I'm at it - please stop slating people for adding water or ice to their dram. Its great. Also - stop harping on about the peatiness coming from the water, its nonesense. Thank you please || I drink it and I like it. But it’s too short on the finish and missing half of the palate. It is a bottle of all of the elements I love about Glenlivet, but too fast and not enough. With no pause in between. || A nice way to enter the single malts world and not just on the price. This is a smooth, gentle and fresh whisky with sweet citric nose notes, specially orange. It has a soft creamy mouthfill and keeps the orange promise with a middle persistence, also apple and candy tastes can be noticed. The finish stays on the smooth range with a spicy touch. On a sunny day, at the beach or by the pool this bottle will work for everyone, specially the non initiated and that's what I guess is the focus of this expression.
flavour_note: Apple, Pear, Grass, Toffee Delicate aromas of citrus fruit, notably sweet orange. Sweet, fruit notes of zesty oranges and pears, with a hint of candy, toffee apples. Well-balanced and exceptionally smooth. Long, creamy and smooth.

Unfortunately have to disagree with a previous reviewer, for me it had a strong peaty note.

name: 20 Year Old Speyside Cognac FinishWhisky Works
characters: Violet, Grapefruit, Milk Chocolate, Cream, Strawberry, Ginger
nose: Barley sugar and toffee, candy necklaces and sweet butter. Floral notes develop along with fragrant grassiness. Soft notes of mint fondant hide at the back with building butter, toffee and butterscotch notes over the top.
palate: Candied flowers lead, with Glacier Mints, sherbet lemons and sharp apples to follow. Gently spicy oak, ginger and a touch of polished wood develop. Hob-nob oats and sweet butter biscuits develop, balanced by sweet royal icing and touch of sour apple.
finish: Soft but long, with a burst of sawdust fading to leave mint cream, apple sauce a touch of old damp oak. Sweet butter icing lingers.
reviews: Really nice whisky. Aromatic, sweet and fruity. Im usually an Islay drinker but this makes me want to change sides. Would love to see a sample set of all their whiskies!
flavour_note: Violet, Grapefruit, Milk Chocolate, Cream, Strawberry, Ginger Barley sugar and toffee, candy necklaces and sweet butter. Floral notes develop along with fragrant grassiness. Soft notes of mint fondant hide at the back with building butter, toffee and butterscotch notes over the top. Candied flowers lead, with Glacier Mints, sherbet lemons and sharp apples to follow. Gently spicy oak, ginger and a touch of polished wood develop. Hob-nob oats and sweet butter biscuits develop, balanced by sweet royal icing and touch of sour apple. Soft but long, with a burst of sawdust fading to leave mint cream, apple sauce a touch of old damp oak. Sweet butter icing lingers.

name: Glen Moray Peated
characters: Leather, Smoke, Vanilla, Cream, Rhubarb, Cinnamon
nose: Layers of peat with background of vanilla. Tangy rhubarb and hints of leather.
reviews: I thought this was a great buy, very drinkable and not as peaty as some of the Islay malts. Well worth the price and let the whisky snobs stay with their overpriced bottles. || This is such a pleasant change from the "smack in the mouth" peat you generally get from Islay. Because the peat used to dry the malt in Glen Moray is cut in the highlands, its constituent plants are very different from the coastal plants found on Islay. Resulting in a lovely peaty nose that is unmistakable, that is followed with a smoother and sweeter taste yet still quite spicy. For the current price, there are few peated malts to compare, and pretty much nothing from the Highlands that comes close. It's easily worth double, simply because Highland Peated Whisky is so rare. || Having bought this on a whim for £18 in a supermarket six months ago I've just got round to trying it.Bearing in mind I don't like Speyside as a rule this was out of character.Anyhow,credit where credit is due this is quite nice.Lovely peaty taste with a refreshing rhubarb undertone.I will quite happily polish this bottle off and buy another.3.75/5 || The character/personality is very good, but in the palate its youth is obvious. The smoke doen't quite cover up the "spirity" taste. Not a lot of complexity here, but still a very nice dram. || Yes I have tried this whiskey and I really like it as I like Smokey whiskey
flavour_note: Leather, Smoke, Vanilla, Cream, Rhubarb, Cinnamon Layers of peat with background of vanilla. Tangy rhubarb and hints of leather. Long, sweet and spicy.

name: Glen Moray Port Cask Finish
characters: Honey, Dark Chocolate, Nutmeg, Lemon, Cinnamon, Oak
nose: First impressions are of toasted vanilla and subtle hints of oak. Aromas of rich dried fruits and leather follow, laced with dark chocolate and blackberries.
finish: The finish is smooth with soft oak and honey sweetness lingering gently on the tongue. The spice continues to tingle and dark chocolate flavours develop to give luxurious texture and a fitting finale to an elegant whisky.
reviews: A port finished scotch for a reasonable price? Count me in! Dried plums, apricots and peach, with some oak in the background. It tastes very young and definitely needs a drop or two of water to open up. Quite pleasant once you get past the harshness. You can definitely taste the port cask influence here. || I was quite hopeful. "Decent for the price" was what I'd come to expect based on the reviews. No significant nose to speak of. Thin body, overly sweet with not much else to offset it. Had two drinks, and poured it out. A waste, really, but I was rather disappointed. Your mileage may vary. || Solid for the price, but I don’t love the flavor. It’s peachy, kinda cheap. I’m sure this is better quality than Dewars White, but tastes similar. || Not too strong, oaky taste. Pleasant to drink. || Amazing for the price. I get it, sweeter-end whiskys are not for everyone, but I like it. Works very well as a dessert whisky too.
flavour_note: Honey, Dark Chocolate, Nutmeg, Lemon, Cinnamon, Oak First impressions are of toasted vanilla and subtle hints of oak. Aromas of rich dried fruits and leather follow, laced with dark chocolate and blackberries. The finish is smooth with soft oak and honey sweetness lingering gently on the tongue. The spice continues to tingle and dark chocolate flavours develop to give luxurious texture and a fitting finale to an elegant whisky.

name: Balvenie 17 Year OldIslay Cask
reviews: Lovely. Absolutely a worthwhile addition to the Balvenie canon. I hope they repeat the release.

name: Auchroisk 201211 Year Old Amarone Cask Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cherry, Dark Chocolate, Marzipan, Dried Fruit, Raisins, Vanilla
nose: Sultanas, crystallised sugar and chocolate cake – Black Forest Gâteau and Mr Kipling’s Country Slices. Almond paste and Florentines develop alongside juicy fresh cherries and slightly sour apple sauce.
palate: Richly textured and intense. Singed notes lead: burnt autumn leaves and old coal stoves. Stewed orchard fruit follows, studded with sultanas and dried cherries. Dark chocolate cake lingers at the back.
finish: Spice lingers, with dark chocolate, damp bark and a touch of dried apple.
flavour_note: Cherry, Dark Chocolate, Marzipan, Dried Fruit, Raisins, Vanilla Sultanas, crystallised sugar and chocolate cake – Black Forest Gâteau and Mr Kipling’s Country Slices. Almond paste and Florentines develop alongside juicy fresh cherries and slightly sour apple sauce. Richly textured and intense. Singed notes lead: burnt autumn leaves and old coal stoves. Stewed orchard fruit follows, studded with sultanas and dried cherries. Dark chocolate cake lingers at the back. Spice lingers, with dark chocolate, damp bark and a touch of dried apple.

name: Benrinnes 199626 Year Old Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cinnamon, Vanilla, Apple, Fruit Cake, Cream, Oak
nose: Light fruitcake with glacé cherries and baking spice, slathered with butter. Sweet apples and pears follow along with a touch of malt loaf, barley sugar and vanilla cream. After a few minutes strawberries push through the cream, followed by salted butter.
palate: Big sweetness to start: mint fondant and crème pâtissière. Polished oak and woody spice build, balanced by stewed apple and buttered toast.
finish: Toffee, apples and mint slowly fade, leaving soft spice and vanilla.
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Vanilla, Apple, Fruit Cake, Cream, Oak Light fruitcake with glacé cherries and baking spice, slathered with butter. Sweet apples and pears follow along with a touch of malt loaf, barley sugar and vanilla cream. After a few minutes strawberries push through the cream, followed by salted butter. Big sweetness to start: mint fondant and crème pâtissière. Polished oak and woody spice build, balanced by stewed apple and buttered toast. Toffee, apples and mint slowly fade, leaving soft spice and vanilla.

name: Glen Keith 199329 Year Old Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Malt, Toffee, Apple, Mango, Cream, Banana
nose: Sweet cream with apple, mango and a touch of olive oil – green and grassy. Barley-sugar sweetness and pink shrimp sweets are backed up by gentle maltiness.
palate: Meaty grain, mint fondant and rich butter cream. The grain falls beneath the cream as gentle toffee sauce notes develop. Then comes a wave of fruit: apples, pears, bananas and slightly underripe mangoes.
finish: Salty butter and white toast followed by toffee, apples and soft spice.
flavour_note: Malt, Toffee, Apple, Mango, Cream, Banana Sweet cream with apple, mango and a touch of olive oil – green and grassy. Barley-sugar sweetness and pink shrimp sweets are backed up by gentle maltiness. Meaty grain, mint fondant and rich butter cream. The grain falls beneath the cream as gentle toffee sauce notes develop. Then comes a wave of fruit: apples, pears, bananas and slightly underripe mangoes. Salty butter and white toast followed by toffee, apples and soft spice.
