name: Glen Grant 15 Year Old Batch Strength First Edition
characters: Vanilla, Apple, Marmalade, Melon, Cinnamon, Malt
reviews: Got this in a tasting pack. A big pear hit and hint of melon on the nose. Beautiful light colour. Delightfully oily in the glass. After the immediate hit of alcohol, vanilla explodes on the pallet, then spice on a long lingering finish. Added a drop of water to compare. Brings the melon through more, but on the palate, not as good for me. Dampens the alcohol but loses flavour. Definitely one for sipping straight up. Happy to purchase. It's a lovely Speyside dram.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Apple, Marmalade, Melon, Cinnamon, Malt

name: Glenlossie 201010 Year Old Single Malts of Scotland
Tamnavulin German Pinot Noir Cask
reviews: I would say this is actually quite a good whisky. I can only imagine this is a young whisky but it honestly doesn’t taste that way. You can spend £50 for something like Filey Bay or a bit less for Cotswold and this is honestly just better. It’s much richer in fruitiness, I can’t seem to find that ethanol flavour. I’d say it’s the sweet brother of the woody Black Bottle. In fact, mixing the pair in a barrel could be quite special It’s not 5 star because it’s not complex. But the one thing it does do, especially for the price (22 quid for me) is brilliant || Good crowd pleaser, sweeter notes and less smokey for whiskey beginners. The red wine flavour comes through in the scent and adds to a great all round taste. || Now this one is a waste of time.Thank the good lord I only paid £20 for it.Got a finish drier than Noel Coward

name: Glen Keith 1995Jack Wiebers Old Paddle Steamer
characters: Biscuits, Vanilla, White Pepper, Ginger, Lemon
flavour_note: Biscuits, Vanilla, White Pepper, Ginger, Lemon

name: Aberlour A'Bunadh Batch 59
reviews: Not as good as batch 55, but still excellent || This batch 59 is quite disappointing compared to earlier batches. I’ve tried most batches up to 52, and I regarded them as very consistent and always a favourite for me. There is a definite difference with this, still warming, but harsh and not much of a sherry hit on the nose or taste. || Best whiskey from speyside hands down. Came to the US of A really fast || The 59 is a  far less complex and has less depth than the 58.  Sherry notes are diminished substantially. There is a predominance of bitter dark chocolate and spices. The  impression I got was that the spirit hadn’t spent long enough in the barrel or that the barrels were third fill. I was disappointed but as the a’bunadh 59 is widely available at a reduced price it is probably still worth buying...but only just. || This is hardly less alcoholic at nearly 61% than earlier versions.  Adding still water is a must and brings out the  flavours of Citrus fruits and Spices.  As it lingers rich Christmas cake with hints of Ginger  come to the fore with an added subtle influence of polished leather.  A little masterpiece.

name: Speyburn 10 Year Old
reviews: tried one of these in a pub in Cumbria, it was awful but then i got info to the opposite so i bought a bottle. i was really surprised as it is quite a mellow, sweet on the nose, slightly woody dram. methinks someone in a Cumbrian pub hast pulled a fast one, this is definitely the whisly i was served in said establishment. || Smells and tastes exactly like a hospital ward, avoid. || Yes. Affordable speyside single malt. NOT heavy on the smoke/peat. nice & mellow. One of my favorites along with Dewers 12yr blended. || A decent dram, smooth with gentle flavours of Heather citrus & toffee in that order. The spirit is prominent in tasting but I wouldn't add any water, still a good introduction into single malt whisky. || I bought this on a whim because it was more affordable than Glenfiddich 15 solera, I was really amazed at how wonderfully smooth and supple the texture was, and how rich and noteworthy the nose compared to the Glenmorangie 12 I have open. I have been enjoying this bottles evolution as it mellows even more with air, and I found it needed no water to soften. Highly recommended to those with a new-to-scotch palates.
flavour_note: Apple, Orange, Toast, Liquorice root

name: Glenfiddich 30 Year OldSuspended Time Re-imagined Time Series
characters: Oak, Honey, Dried Fruit, Rose, Heather, Nutmeg
nose: Aspects of apple: sharp green apples, toffee apples, apples with toffee sauce. They're joined by barley sugar, sherbet lemons, butterscotch and butter icing. Leafy and fresh-cut grass notes develop, along with creamy toffee, hay and Rich Tea biscuits, with a hint of Garibaldi biscuit following close behind.
palate: Soft rounded and buttery. Old polished oak leads, with creamy toffee following. Spice and sharp apple softens to bright apple sauce with gentle spicing. Spun sugar, barley sugar and gentle char are balanced, supported by a touch sappy oak. Crème brûlée with a singed top rounds things out.
finish: Cinnamon and allspice with apples, skins and pips included. Sweet polished oak, soft char and toffee apples linger, with a hint of aniseed ball heat.
flavour_note: Oak, Honey, Dried Fruit, Rose, Heather, Nutmeg Aspects of apple: sharp green apples, toffee apples, apples with toffee sauce. They're joined by barley sugar, sherbet lemons, butterscotch and butter icing. Leafy and fresh-cut grass notes develop, along with creamy toffee, hay and Rich Tea biscuits, with a hint of Garibaldi biscuit following close behind. Soft rounded and buttery. Old polished oak leads, with creamy toffee following. Spice and sharp apple softens to bright apple sauce with gentle spicing. Spun sugar, barley sugar and gentle char are balanced, supported by a touch sappy oak. Crème brûlée with a singed top rounds things out. Cinnamon and allspice with apples, skins and pips included. Sweet polished oak, soft char and toffee apples linger, with a hint of aniseed ball heat.

reviews: seemed such a good buy, I ordered the 6 set offer for £182.11, intending to give some as gifts, and keep two myself they arrived very well packed indeed. But when unpacking was complete I was extremely dossapointed to find the tumblers are just plain As a presentation offering I expected the glass tumblers to be etched with the name "Singleton" spoilt an otherwise perfect gift || Simple dram

It’s a good whisky - no doubt - but it’s not great. There will be better alternatives for what this tries to do. || Just sat down to this??If you like Smokey , this is one of the best?? || A fine rich peaty and very smoky dram to be had with a few drops of water to bring out it secrets. An acquired taste over time is required and one not for the faint of heart but will be sure to warm it. I would highly recommend Benriach Smoky 10 as a pleasant down to earth dram. || Very good

name: Dalwhinnie Winter's Gold
nose: Classic Dalwhinnie aromas of flowers, honey and green fruit – apples and fresh pair. Clean and precise. Nice honeyed warmth, too.
palate: Very soft on the palate, with slightly warming honeyed fruit. Soothing texture, with light floral notes mingling with soft fruits and just a touch of spice.
reviews: A lovely smooth sweet whisky. || Loved it.  Very smooth.  Great flavor. || Yes.   The Winter Gold was fabulous! It went down smoothly, and then had a comfortable warm glow that was awesome.  The people at the distillery were incredibly wonderful! We had a great time the and loved the whiskey. Can’t for my bottle of  Winter Gold to arrive at my home in upstate New York! || Got it out of Freezer & sipped . Unique ! Heavenly , Superb , delicious. Gr8 for special occassion. Enjoy || A lovely whisky. Normally out of my price range, I buy it when it is on offer.
flavour_note: Heather, Nutmeg, Honey, Smoke, Malt Classic Dalwhinnie aromas of flowers, honey and green fruit – apples and fresh pair. Clean and precise. Nice honeyed warmth, too. Very soft on the palate, with slightly warming honeyed fruit. Soothing texture, with light floral notes mingling with soft fruits and just a touch of spice. Soft spice and sweet honey.

name: Glenrothes 18 Year Old
characters: Orange, Vanilla, Pear, Rose, Ginger, Almond
nose: Orange oil, vanilla pods, pear and almonds.
palate: Sweet, ginger, rose water, pears and vanilla.
reviews: Truly delicious! Has notes of vanilla, ginger, rose, orange and pear, as advertised. In addition, this new Soleo Collection release has an amazingly deep taste - and aroma - of soft, chewy caramel. The kind of soft, chewy, homemade, melts-in-your-mouth individually wrapped caramel sold occasionally at speciality stores. This was my first Glenrothes, and it’s a knock-out. Not a sherry-bomb, but rather the perfect amount of sweetness, with far more depth than I expected based on color alone (as compared to some of the other 18-year old whiskies I’ve imbibed over the years). This one is a keeper and will now occupy the sacred top-shelf area of my cupboard along with three or four other elderly (18-25 year) Scottish cousins. Also, hats off to the great folks at Whisky Exchange, whose shipments always arrive quickly and in perfect condition to my home In Hillsboro, Oregon (USA).
flavour_note: Orange, Vanilla, Pear, Rose, Ginger, Almond Orange oil, vanilla pods, pear and almonds. Sweet, ginger, rose water, pears and vanilla. Sweet, spicy and slightly peppery.

characters: Sherry, Orange, Dark Chocolate, Oak, Figs
nose: Dunnage warehouses and sniffed sherry-cask bungholes – about as close to smelling a whisky in a warehouse as you can get while not in a warehouse. Spiced sponge cake with raisins, sultanas and mixed peel. Malt loaf, fruit loaf, baking spice, sour cherry jam and brown-sugar cookies.
palate: Balanced dark fruit and polished oak. Dry with flashes of brown sugar, spiced fruitcake, maraschino cherries, sandalwood, incense, sharp apple peel, dark chocolate and orange zest.
finish: Cherry jam and baking spice, with stewed apples and lingering damp oak.
flavour_note: Sherry, Orange, Dark Chocolate, Oak, Figs Dunnage warehouses and sniffed sherry-cask bungholes – about as close to smelling a whisky in a warehouse as you can get while not in a warehouse. Spiced sponge cake with raisins, sultanas and mixed peel. Malt loaf, fruit loaf, baking spice, sour cherry jam and brown-sugar cookies. Balanced dark fruit and polished oak. Dry with flashes of brown sugar, spiced fruitcake, maraschino cherries, sandalwood, incense, sharp apple peel, dark chocolate and orange zest. Cherry jam and baking spice, with stewed apples and lingering damp oak.

name: Glenfarclas 15 Year OldBot.1980s Selected for Gray & Adams
Imperial 34 Year OldSingle Malts Of Scotland Director's Special
Dallas Dhu 197720 Year Old First Cask #1118
Hakushu Distiller's Reserve
characters: Grapefruit, Smoke, Melon, Mixed Herb, Eucalyptus, Apple
nose: Quite herbaceous. Green fruit, mint, cucumber, pine, grassy, spearmint. Just loads of green fruit in this one.
palate: Loads of green things coming out of here! Mint, cucumber, green fruit, grapefruit and just a touch of smoke at the back. Dave Broom got yuzu…I’ve never heard of yuzu….
finish: Light, delicate, refreshing and some subtle smoke.
reviews:
I agree with the other reviews. It tasted clean with no after taste. The cucumber reference is well deserved as it tastes fresh. 
Easily drunk neat. Be careful as you’ll drink too much! || Under-rated in my opinion- mainly, it’s very interesting in flavour, not a deep layered whisky but also unlike most, so I liked it for that reason || A young lively bright whisky.  On the nose: a cool breathe of mint and vanilla coming from the strong interaction  with American oak, the Japanese change of seasons is truly present in this malt. Floral perfume, melon. Some hints of smoke and earthy moss. On the palate: creamy and clear as spring water, very in line with the nose. Not very deep, but lively and focussed.  It is said to contain a lightly peated young spirit above 8yo and a strongly peated spirit above 18yo. The younger whisky sets the tone: a great serene character which reflects the pine forests  around the distillery (and less complex than the Hakushu 12yo). || A truly special whisky. It's very Green, a start that commences with a fruity mouth like biting info a fresh apple after settling swallowing ice cold water with lime and mint in it.... Then a subtle lapsang souchong flavoured shortbread finish.   I can't do this justice and I'm normally very verbose || This is our favourite Japanese whisky. It is clean and refreshing. We once visited the distillery where Hakushu was produced, and fell in love with this. They did something called 'highball from the wood' using Hakushu, which was sublime. Last year, we discovered as its popularity soared, Suntory had run out of the liquid and stopped shipping Hakushu as well as Yamazaki. I was therefore very pleased to find a reasonably priced bottle of Hakushu on Whisky Exchange.
flavour_note: Grapefruit, Smoke, Melon, Mixed Herb, Eucalyptus, Apple Quite herbaceous. Green fruit, mint, cucumber, pine, grassy, spearmint. Just loads of green fruit in this one. Loads of green things coming out of here! Mint, cucumber, green fruit, grapefruit and just a touch of smoke at the back. Dave Broom got yuzu…I’ve never heard of yuzu…. Light, delicate, refreshing and some subtle smoke.

name: Hibiki Harmony
characters: Apricot, Orange, Cinnamon, Oak, Black Pepper
reviews: to spicee and to harsh. i think its over hiped and ovepriced. few years back when 12 years old hibiki was about £50 , price was more reasonable... || Excellent whisky, with an unique flavor, mild, gentle, floral, fruity and sandalwood notes, thanks to the influence of mizunara casks. I rate this as the best whisky outside Scotland in the NAS segment. Tastes like a Speysider, blended with a Lowland whisky, smooth, sweet and blissfully aromatic. || I tried this chilled but without ice. It had a lovely fruity-cum-spicy aroma and taste. Although I really enjoyed it, I didn't think it was a significant improvement on my usual single malt. || Striking amber colour with a pleasant aroma, drank over ice it was smooth with a subtle bite but no prolonged after taste. Very nice over all and would be a welcome gift. || Great tasting whiskey
flavour_note: Apricot, Orange, Cinnamon, Oak, Black Pepper

characters: Orange, Cinnamon, Honey, Pineapple, Nutmeg, Smoke
nose: Maple syrup, white grapes and honeysuckle lead a soft and spicy character.
palate: Spice starts, fading beneath caramel, sweet orange and cinnamon toast.
reviews: real burster || evething is fine except the packaging was slightly damaged thanks || Very good! Light and crisp. Not overly fruity. Dangerously smooth, great as a slow sipper or shot. Neat or on rock, doesn’t matter. Good stuff will buy again! || As others have said, if you like Speyside this will be right up your street. I saw it in Sainsbury's a few years for £45 and snapped it up, was probably £55-60 here the previous time I bought it. Can't understand why its so much more now. There are better bottles in this range, I can assure you. || I like Yamazaki 12 as I find it quite smooth and relatively easy to drink. Back in the day when you could find a bottle for £60 I would just about stretch to buying one (on a special occasion). But for £135 I just don’t think it’s worth it, you can find whisky which is just as good for far cheaper, and if your budget for a bottle is £135 you can find something truly special! Very pleasant and easy to drink, but not worth the price by a long way.
flavour_note: Orange, Cinnamon, Honey, Pineapple, Nutmeg, Smoke Maple syrup, white grapes and honeysuckle lead a soft and spicy character. Spice starts, fading beneath caramel, sweet orange and cinnamon toast. Grape skin and pineapple.

name: Hibiki 21 Year Old
characters: Honeycomb, Apricot, Blackberry, Banana, Smoke, Toffee
reviews: The good: this is simply the smoothest and best whisky I've tasted recently. The bad: I will be a long time consumer and statistic of this fine whiskey and the demand for it... Well done Hibiki! || Best whiskey I've ever had || A very pleasant experience. || champion of champions...one of the best blended whisky under the sun...the bot gets finished in no time...easier to drink than water,smoother than honey...
flavour_note: Honeycomb, Apricot, Blackberry, Banana, Smoke, Toffee

name: Yamazaki Distiller's Reserve
nose: The wine cask seems to dominate the nose here with strawberries and red fruit taking centre stage. However, sitting quietly in the background is the incense from the mizunara, a hint of dried fruit from the sherry cask and a touch of coconut.
palate: An abundance of red fruit again, with raspberries, strawberries and even redcurrants coming through, although there’s more dimensions to this than the first wine cask sample that we tried. White peach, a hint of wood and spice, back-up notes of red cherries and candied fruits all come into play here as well.
finish: Relatively long finish with vanilla and sweet spice dancing around the tongue.
reviews: I preferred this over their 12YO. || Bought this bottle. Very nice really smooth and lovely t drink || Well balanced, excellent flavors and good with ice shaken or on its own! One of the best around. || Absolutely beautiful took this wiskey home from Japan. Its rich and fruity lovely nose of vanilla fruity raisins touch of oak. || Terrible
flavour_note: Raspberry, Strawberry, Peach, Cherry, Vanilla The wine cask seems to dominate the nose here with strawberries and red fruit taking centre stage. However, sitting quietly in the background is the incense from the mizunara, a hint of dried fruit from the sherry cask and a touch of coconut. An abundance of red fruit again, with raspberries, strawberries and even redcurrants coming through, although there’s more dimensions to this than the first wine cask sample that we tried. White peach, a hint of wood and spice, back-up notes of red cherries and candied fruits all come into play here as well. Relatively long finish with vanilla and sweet spice dancing around the tongue.

name: Suntory Toki
characters: Apple, Grape, Grapefruit, Mint, White Pepper, Ginger
finish: Subtly sweet and spicy finish with a hint of vanilla oak, white pepper and ginger.
reviews: This is Suntory's cheaper whisky intended for drinking as a highball, so not surprising people aren't keen on drinking it neat || This is not my first time drinking Japanese whisky, but it might be my last now. This is very poor, very hot and much too young. Japanese whisky used to be a much better product. What a shame. || I have tried several different Japanese whiskies. This is my least favorite. It is too strong to drink neat. I will try it as a highball where I think it will be much more enjoyable. A few notes of fruit and herbs but falls short on complexity and refinement. || This was my first time trying a Japanese whisky, and I'm very impressed. Pleasant aromas of honey and pine resin that carry through on to the palate, where they're joined by floral notes, a hint of citrus, and a slight pepper spice. I'm definitely in unfamiliar territory here, as my go-to is any bottle full of smoke and peat from Islay, but I found this very pleasant and easy to drink. I'll certainly be back for more! || First time trying out the Japanese whisky brands and I must say this isn't bad introduction for the price. Still a scotch whisky drinker, but I cant wait and try Suntory other brands of the Asian market.
flavour_note: Apple, Grape, Grapefruit, Mint, White Pepper, Ginger Basil, green apple, honey. Grapefruit, green grapes, peppermint, thyme. Subtly sweet and spicy finish with a hint of vanilla oak, white pepper and ginger.

name: The Chita Distiller's Reserve
characters: Vanilla, Cardamom, Nutmeg, Mint, Honey, Rose
reviews: Recently in Japan a local bought us Highballs made with this whiskey, even the whiskey itself is delectable. Happy to have made this order, everyone please try it!
flavour_note: Vanilla, Cardamom, Nutmeg, Mint, Honey, Rose

name: Nikka Coffey Grain Whisky
nose: Sweeter and fruitier than the Coffey Malt, this is has oodles of sweet spice, mango and papaya aromas, candied orange peel and coconut.
palate: Toffee popcorn, with more of that heady citrus and tropical fruit. Quite a mouthful.
finish: Not especially long lasting; rich oak and marmalade notes dominate.
reviews: Lovely smooth and mellow whisky. || This is my 2nd Japanese I've tried out and it was great. It was strong at first but with some distilled water it had the sweet taste of some fruit, and bit of vanilla. Excellent work at the Nikka distillery. || Delicious! Tropical fruits and spice. All enveloping with a lot going on. A dram you keep wanting to come back to || The sweetness is just magical! || Excellent
flavour_note: Mango, Papaya, Orange, Cinnamon, Coconut Sweeter and fruitier than the Coffey Malt, this is has oodles of sweet spice, mango and papaya aromas, candied orange peel and coconut. Toffee popcorn, with more of that heady citrus and tropical fruit. Quite a mouthful. Not especially long lasting; rich oak and marmalade notes dominate.

name: Yoichi Single Malt
characters: Smoke, Seashell, Salt (powder), Lemon, Apple, Oak
nose: Full-bodied, smooth. A mellow peat softly coats the aromatic palette at first, growing more powerful with time, as smoke, soot and salty notes transcend the initial nose. The aromas then evolve towards candied citrus fruit (lemon, orange), black liquorice and spices (nutmeg, ginger), and opens up with roots and dried twig aromas. Heady and floral (carnation, iris), it grows increasingly complex.
palate: Firm, powerful. A well-balanced attack gives equal footing to aromas of peat, smoke, spices, fresh fruit (melon, kiwi) and nuts (almond, walnut), which it delivers in spades. The mid-palate starts off with chocolate notes, but the peat soon takes the lead once again.
finish: Long, silky. Extremely mature, it overflows with ripe fruit (pear, Mirabelle plum, apple). The peat starts taking on an herbaceous and malty character, while the salty flavours gives the finish plenty of depth and coastal freshness. The final nose offers menthol, spicy (coriander, dill) and earthy (leather, chestnuts) notes.
reviews: Tried this at the Whisky Fringe and have it my vote for best dram. Fruity and smooth. Didn't even add water, a lovely dram || Smooth || Very smooth and balanced and very good value for money || This isnt a bad product. In fact it retails for ~25 quid in Japan, which is about right. In the UK you'd be far better off with some fine Scottish malt if you're spending 70 odd pounds, imho. Still its a reasonable drink you can buy at the local (japanese) supermarket. I bought 2 yesterday and 2 Miyagikyo-the same price and same reasoning. Its cheap and reasonable. Dont expect a song and dance. || Extremely smooth and dry. Strong taste and extremely pleasant aftertaste. My favorite whiskey.
flavour_note: Smoke, Seashell, Salt (powder), Lemon, Apple, Oak Full-bodied, smooth. A mellow peat softly coats the aromatic palette at first, growing more powerful with time, as smoke, soot and salty notes transcend the initial nose. The aromas then evolve towards candied citrus fruit (lemon, orange), black liquorice and spices (nutmeg, ginger), and opens up with roots and dried twig aromas. Heady and floral (carnation, iris), it grows increasingly complex. Firm, powerful. A well-balanced attack gives equal footing to aromas of peat, smoke, spices, fresh fruit (melon, kiwi) and nuts (almond, walnut), which it delivers in spades. The mid-palate starts off with chocolate notes, but the peat soon takes the lead once again. Long, silky. Extremely mature, it overflows with ripe fruit (pear, Mirabelle plum, apple). The peat starts taking on an herbaceous and malty character, while the salty flavours gives the finish plenty of depth and coastal freshness. The final nose offers menthol, spicy (coriander, dill) and earthy (leather, chestnuts) notes.

name: Miyagikyo Single Malt
nose: Full-flavoured, rich. Initially, concentrated iris notes hint at the extreme intensity of the nose. It then develops aromas of malted barley, exotic fruit (banana), liquorice and camphor. Notes of burnt wood and ash progressively settle over the aromatic palette. Long after, white flowers and beeswax make an appearance.
palate: Firm, lively. Malted barley is at the heart of the palate, coated in herbaceous, liquorice, spiced (ginger, cinnamon) and chocolate tones. Very elegant, the mid-palate also delivers plenty of energy and as it draws to a close, fresh tobacco leaves and coconut intertwine to create a natural symphony of aromas.
finish: Long, soft. It evokes the scent of wilted roses. Fine tannins balance its tangy character (lemon, grapefruit). It lingers on notes of tobacco, spices (cardamom, ginger), toasted nuts and stewed fruits (apple, damson). The final nose reveals exotic notes (lychee).
reviews: Bloody well fantastic || Thin body as in description, but I like the taste....not particularly complex and there are a lot better whiskies out there for this price || Smooth floral notes || Not worth the price tag at all! Very young spirits used, flavours are one dimensional. Overall this whisky is very forgettable. Unfortunately, Japanese whisky's popularity is having a negative effect on the quality as distilleries are struggling to keep up with demand. || Shared the bottle with friends. A great Sunday afternoon lunch finished with a very good Japanese single malt.
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Ginger, Tobacco, Coconut, Apple Full-flavoured, rich. Initially, concentrated iris notes hint at the extreme intensity of the nose. It then develops aromas of malted barley, exotic fruit (banana), liquorice and camphor. Notes of burnt wood and ash progressively settle over the aromatic palette. Long after, white flowers and beeswax make an appearance. Firm, lively. Malted barley is at the heart of the palate, coated in herbaceous, liquorice, spiced (ginger, cinnamon) and chocolate tones. Very elegant, the mid-palate also delivers plenty of energy and as it draws to a close, fresh tobacco leaves and coconut intertwine to create a natural symphony of aromas. Long, soft. It evokes the scent of wilted roses. Fine tannins balance its tangy character (lemon, grapefruit). It lingers on notes of tobacco, spices (cardamom, ginger), toasted nuts and stewed fruits (apple, damson). The final nose reveals exotic notes (lychee).

name: Onikishi Japanese Blended Whisky
flavour_note: Vanilla, Caramel, Oak, Yuzu

name: Hakushu 12 Year Old
nose: Honey, lemon and a little ginger.
palate: Delicacy to the fore. A breakfast dram if there were ever one.
finish: Fruity and sweet. Ripe cherry plums, almond milk, acacia honey.
reviews: 2nd bottle of Japanese whisky and my favorite. Added one ice cube on recommendation and added another level of complexity and balance. Loved it! || My absolute favourite fr the Suntory stable. A whisky for contemplation when time stood still as the world goes by. || My first foray into the Japanese single malts (all other Jap whiskies I've tried to date have been blends) and this did *not* disappoint. Very light color, a bit more on the nose than I'm used to for the Jap stuff but wow what delightful flavours. So well balanced and refined. Subtle smokiness and peat with the slight sweetness of the pear as a delicious aftertaste. An ice cube or two gives you 3 or 4 different drinks as the water seemingly opens up different compartments of this complex, and yet light/delicate single malt. Definitely at the top of my list of Japanese whisky thus far. An easy 5 stars. || My first foray into the Japanese single malts (all other Jap whiskies I've tried to date have been blends) and this did *not* disappoint. Very light color, a bit more on the nose than I'm used to for the Jap stuff but wow what delightful flavours. So well balanced and refined. Subtle smokiness and peat with the slight sweetness of the pear as a delicious aftertaste. An ice cube or two gives you 3 or 4 different drinks as the water seemingly opens up different compartments of this complex, and yet light/delicate single malt. Definitely at the top of my list of Japanese whisky thus far. An easy 5 stars. || I had heard that Japanese whiskey was something to behold. I was in the market for my usual Bowmore and Lagavulin but felt compelled to pick up a bottle to see what the Japanese with a single malt. WOW!!! I was blown away after the first sip! Light, citrus up front followed by a smooth sweetness. The perfect dram for a hot summer evening in Arizona. I highly recommend his masterful whiskey.
flavour_note: Pear, Lemon, Leaves, Smoke, Wax Honey, lemon and a little ginger. Delicacy to the fore. A breakfast dram if there were ever one. Fruity and sweet. Ripe cherry plums, almond milk, acacia honey.

name: Ichiro's Malt Double Distilleries(46.5%)
reviews: Have wanted to get a taste of the legendary Hanyu and Chichibu distilleries from Japanese whisky rockstar Akuto-san, but prices for their ultra-limited single malts and single casks are crazy, despite being often just aged for 3-5 years. It's hard to separate the hype from the substance unless you taste it for yourself. I found it to have a pretty strong initial oaky impact on the tongue, but a wonderful complexity of flavors and strong finish. I don't have the nose to give more tasting notes, but suffice to say it was a unique experience and worth the wait and price. || I was pleasantly surprised. Definitely worth the wait.

finish: Creamy chocolate, cherry jam and cinnamon spice, with lingering clove and baked apple.
reviews: Absolutely love this. || The first time I will be trying
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Orange, Black tea, Custard, Banana, Peat smoke Raisins, gravel and cooling cast-iron stoves. Brown sugar and sultanas build with a touch of liquorice and barbecue wood smoke. Chocolate and toasty bread notes develop. Rich and oily, with gentle heat and chocolatey smoke. Log fires and singed raisins follow, along with cherry jam and green apples. Earthiness hides underneath, alongside more chocolate and hints of mint and moss. Creamy chocolate, cherry jam and cinnamon spice, with lingering clove and baked apple.

name: Shirakawa 1958
nose: Resinous, slight dry earth, dried citrus peels, a hint of wax. Aromatic. A drop of water makes it more vibrant and also shows clear maturity as well as a hint of incense. Exotic.
palate: The palate is expansive with a succulent texture and hints of fragrant grass. Fruits emerge in the middle. Layered, spiced, and dry. Water brings out ash from an incense burner, a satisfying mouthfeel and surprisingly perky acidity.
finish: Nicely balanced and persistent on the finish which picks up mint flavouring and makes it more camphor-like.
reviews: Lovely smooth whiskey with a gorgeous fruity aftertaste delicious. || It is definitely a refined and luxurious whiskey. It is also quite different in that the nose is more exotic than fruity. In the perfume world nose is roughly split between floral aromas, rose, lavender etc and exotic musk resinous, sandalwood or spice. The 1958 is out and out exotic, musky and just a touch of lemon. It benefits from a touch of water to open up those exotics but when it does, oh yes, wonderful.
flavour_note: Lemon, Grass, Wax, Resin, Mint Resinous, slight dry earth, dried citrus peels, a hint of wax. Aromatic. A drop of water makes it more vibrant and also shows clear maturity as well as a hint of incense. Exotic. The palate is expansive with a succulent texture and hints of fragrant grass. Fruits emerge in the middle. Layered, spiced, and dry. Water brings out ash from an incense burner, a satisfying mouthfeel and surprisingly perky acidity. Nicely balanced and persistent on the finish which picks up mint flavouring and makes it more camphor-like.

name: Yoichi 200020 Year Old Anniversary Blend ltd Edition
Karuizawa 199515 Year Old Distillery Exclusive Cask #2034
The Whisky Exchange 37 Year Old Blended MaltGastronomy Selection
nose: Fine Devon fudge and butter toffee, made with milk from undisturbed cows, the finest hand-spun cane sugar and sea-salted, long-cultured farmhouse butter. Freshly shelled hazelnuts and Swiss milk chocolate follow, a crunch-laden enrobing with a sprinkling of finely julienned orange zest. The creaminess builds, packed with gentle Madagascan vanilla character and hints of cream-laden coffee: thick, dark, sweet Rwandan beans, brewed over flame in a Japanese siphon.
palate: The notes of creamy sweetness return, rolling over unsnapped single-origin chocolate shards into a pool of bobbing windfall apples: tart Granny Smith and sweet Pink Lady with a handful of transatlantic Honeycrisp. The nutty notes develop: hazelnuts from the bottom of the bowl with lightly toasted Spanish almonds, all lightly dusted with soft, golden caster sugar. Crunchy spun-sugar nests are draped over thinly sliced conference pears and freshly malted Golden Promise barley. Beeswax-polished oak is sprinkled with gently bruised mint leaves.
finish: Rich, baked-apple purée builds in waves, lingering beyond developing mint and creamy caramel. Chocolate water-ganache, let down with cream, leads to polished oak off-cuts and honey-baked vanilla pods.
reviews: 37 year old malt whisky for £119 - TWE take a bow! On the nose, old leather & dusty library books w/ a little hessian & apple pie. A thick & waxy arrival is followed by flavours of milk chocolate, dried mango & juicy sultanas. Unbelievable value ?? || Was ok in my steak pepper sauce. || This is easily the best whisky I have never had!! The subtly is so in your face that it comes in huge waves of nothingness. My one disappointment with this bottle is that I get no buzz even after drinking nearly the entire bottle in one sitting.
flavour_note: Hazelnut, Toffee, Caramel, Apple, Pear Fine Devon fudge and butter toffee, made with milk from undisturbed cows, the finest hand-spun cane sugar and sea-salted, long-cultured farmhouse butter. Freshly shelled hazelnuts and Swiss milk chocolate follow, a crunch-laden enrobing with a sprinkling of finely julienned orange zest. The creaminess builds, packed with gentle Madagascan vanilla character and hints of cream-laden coffee: thick, dark, sweet Rwandan beans, brewed over flame in a Japanese siphon. The notes of creamy sweetness return, rolling over unsnapped single-origin chocolate shards into a pool of bobbing windfall apples: tart Granny Smith and sweet Pink Lady with a handful of transatlantic Honeycrisp. The nutty notes develop: hazelnuts from the bottom of the bowl with lightly toasted Spanish almonds, all lightly dusted with soft, golden caster sugar. Crunchy spun-sugar nests are draped over thinly sliced conference pears and freshly malted Golden Promise barley. Beeswax-polished oak is sprinkled with gently bruised mint leaves. Rich, baked-apple purée builds in waves, lingering beyond developing mint and creamy caramel. Chocolate water-ganache, let down with cream, leads to polished oak off-cuts and honey-baked vanilla pods.

name: Dad's Dram Blended MaltThe Whisky Exchange
characters: Apple, Caramel, Pastries, Gooseberry, Toffee, Milk Chocolate
nose: Baked apples, caramel sauce, spiced shortbread, poached pears, baking spice and hints of polished oak. Fresher notes of crunchy apple, gooseberry and redcurrants develop alongside soft ginger nut biscuit touches and a little bit of milk chocolate.
palate: Apples and pears to start: baked, poached and in a pie. The pastry is gently spiced, with cinnamon and nutmeg, dusted with brown sugar and served with a dollop of sharp apple sauce. Creamy toffee sauce notes build, along with hints of vanilla custard and raisins.
finish: Sweet apples and a touch of granny smith apples, with gooseberries, green leaves and a touch of wax-polished oak.
flavour_note: Apple, Caramel, Pastries, Gooseberry, Toffee, Milk Chocolate Baked apples, caramel sauce, spiced shortbread, poached pears, baking spice and hints of polished oak. Fresher notes of crunchy apple, gooseberry and redcurrants develop alongside soft ginger nut biscuit touches and a little bit of milk chocolate. Apples and pears to start: baked, poached and in a pie. The pastry is gently spiced, with cinnamon and nutmeg, dusted with brown sugar and served with a dollop of sharp apple sauce. Creamy toffee sauce notes build, along with hints of vanilla custard and raisins. Sweet apples and a touch of granny smith apples, with gooseberries, green leaves and a touch of wax-polished oak.

name: Monkey Shoulder
nose: Zesty orange meets mellow vanilla, honey and spiced oak.
reviews: Better than Pinch and other high priced Scotch. || My go to whisky when I feel like a dram of a night, or a cheering glass with a friend. At this level I rate it top of the class! || Sweat smooth creamy vanilla mild spice. Very subtle easy drinking, don't expect the complexity of malts costing twice the price. || Great for the price. Good enough to drink on it's own yet great for cocktails as well. || Very plain taste, not for seasoned drinkers. Lacks complexity. Very smooth and easy to drink though.
flavour_note: Orange, Vanilla, Honey, Oak Zesty orange meets mellow vanilla, honey and spiced oak. Super smooth.

For the price point alone this is an outstanding blend.Once tasted it shows what a classy piece of work this is.Not to be missed.A brilliant flight opener! || Really impressive at such a price. A pretty whisky. || Saw this as a nomination at this years OSWA so  I bought a bottle. What a belter 48.5%  and 8 yr, NCF and nat colour whats not to like.
I only get a trace of smoke but thats not a problem for me, a beautiful blended fruity malt and great value.
Fans of Compass Box- Orchard House I think will like this.
Well done Thompson Bros.

name: Compass Box Orchard House
reviews: Compass box knocks it out of the park again with Orchard house, great sweet, floral and fruit notes.

name: Monkey Shoulder Smokey Monkey
characters: Earth, Smoke, Vanilla, Lemon, Black Pepper
reviews: Love the original monkey shoulder whiskey. Love this one more. || Honestly I’m finding the words to describe it difficult. It tastes like someone messed up, and they decided to add some liquid smoke to the barrel to mask whatever the problem is. Someone else said artificial. I’d agree with that. But it’s more too. It just tastes wrong. Tastes like a cheap plastic bottle of spirits. || Bought this, on a whim... Attracted, by the bottle shape, name; and three monkey badge... Attachec to the bottle... Found its taste, straight up... To be, quite pleasant... And, often NOT in stock; at chain market liquor sections... When, asking a store manager; at Albertsons... As to why? He replied: "Well... Certain employees, usually hide it; behind the more expensive wines... Then buy it, for weekend parties!" I, can see... Why! || Bought on a whim because I like Jonny Walker black and Monkey Shoulder. It tastes artifical and acrid and you will be better spending your money on something else. 1 star, I will not buy this again, I will not reccommend it and I will be pouring my bottle down the sink.
flavour_note: Earth, Smoke, Vanilla, Lemon, Black Pepper

It’s lovely, try it for yourself. || Having tried the Campbeltown Kilkerran which was excellent I'm working my way through the Campbeltown whiskys [what pleasant work]. I was very pleasantly suprised with the Campbeltown Loch.Not being an expert perhaps I'd developed an amateurs snobbery to blended whisky.I've learnt my lesson.It's a beautiful whisky with depth of flavour. || Bought this hoping it would be similiar to the now unbuyable 10 year old that used to be my stock and store. It's not, but it's 80% of the way there, especially on the nose, the finish is a bit flat and undeveloped. But better than most other stuff at £40 a bottle. || The first couple are a bit on the hot side.Letting the bottle breath for a few hours takes most of the heat out and allows things to settle down .From then on water and time make this pure Campbeltown .(3.73/5)

reviews: I have just began my journey with blended whisky and this blended malt is something special! It's the perfect budget dram to crack open with a friend, it's almost dangerously easy to drink. It also makes a great addition to a cocktail if you're that way inclined! :) || I love everything about this whisky. The flavour, smoothness, and long lasting finish. It truly is a bargain. I will be purchasing again || Brilliant dram for the money. I tried this recently at the London Whisky Show and was surprised at how smooth it was. This could easy hold its own against a more expensive single malt at half the price. Highly recommended || This is an great dram especially for the price that it is. This is a blended malt but is extremely smooth and the master blender has done a great job. Warming notes of sherried fruits, spices and sweet vanilla. || A stunning whisky for the price !

name: Compass Box The Peat Monster
nose: Elegant peat smoke with coastal brine, orchard fruit and singed spice.
palate: Smoky and earthy peat, sweet tropical fruit touches and floral notes.
finish: Sweetness lingers, layered with smoke, fruit and delicate meadow-grass character.
reviews: This is my favourite whisky.. || Smooth. Sea spray, Band Aid, earth. Just enough oil and body. Really enjoyable! || The very best blended malt I’ve come across globally, a proper whisky bottled at proper strength with no colouring || This is one of my favourites. I cannot believe how affordable this whisky is. To me, this brings me to a campfire at a ocean beach where I'm eating fruits. The nose is amazing. The taste and finish are really good. I wouldn't call this overly peaty at all. If anything, it's more sea-brine than smoke. They are really nicely balanced. Thinking about it makes my mouth water. I keep reaching forward financially to find something that engages me a little more. It looks like I need to spend about 4x the money for a bottle that is more enjoyable (to me).
flavour_note: Smoke, Brine, Apple, Grass, Heather Elegant peat smoke with coastal brine, orchard fruit and singed spice. Smoky and earthy peat, sweet tropical fruit touches and floral notes. Sweetness lingers, layered with smoke, fruit and delicate meadow-grass character.

name: Collectivum XXVIIISpecial Releases 2017
characters: Dark Chocolate, Lemon, Cinnamon, Smoke, Orange, Apple
nose: Surprisingly mild in feel. The overall aroma is tightly integrated: spicy-sweet and fruity, combining spiky green leaves and dog roses with autumnal forests, toffee and rich vanilla sauce. The greenness comes to dominate, although the sour notes are tempered by sweet brown butter and a slice of candied fruit. Time reveals more herbal notes, with minty toffee and hints of pastry. Water opens all this up, drying and introducing Speyside notes of the sweetshop, with candy and dried apple rings joined by floral touches.
palate: A balance of sweetness, acidity and tannic dryness. Nuts and spice lead, with hazelnuts and almonds joined by bitter walnuts and hot cinnamon. Sweetness builds behind, with candy, barley sugar and sharp candied lemons. The almonds reappear, now sugared, only to disappear amid more citrus, tempered by toffee and fudge spiced with cinnamon, and finally by fruity dark chocolate. Water cools; the smooth sweetness and spice rise, bringing a refreshing bitter note; cream, apple sauce and milk chocolate laced with oak, clove and dark chocolate.
finish: Of medium-length, with buttery pastry, warming spice and a thin layer of sharp fruit; a fresh apple pie ready for the oven. The fruit lingers as apple skin, joined by crisp pear.
reviews: This is possibly the best value whisky I have encountered in decades; closest to a top Brora costing 20 to 30 times the price, touching on all the range that this vaunted and shuttered distillery musters. Of course this is a blend of multiple regions, but you suspect with micro contributions from many and large contributions from a few, particularly leading with a wonderful Clynelish (sibling distillery of the defunct Brora), and a masterfully light backing of an Islay, amongst others. This has a wonderful soaring range. I have both held and participated in single-malt whisky flights with many; this has had only rave responses, and from a wonderfully obscure and very cost-effective blend, that carries itself like an apex lightly-peated highland single-malt. I suspect the unorthodox story and lack of any historical reference lead to what I see as a deep discount, but also make this a wonderful “discovery”. When price and quality come together, I will buy for future years, and have happily loaded up on this one-off to the full extent my budget and conscience would let me. Just brilliant. || A lovely perfumed nose, and then spice, a bit of heat, some smoke, and lots of other things going on and great length. Really lovely whisky, I like a lot! || Superb and complex whisky. Maybe needs drop of water to fully appreciate the taste. Perfect option if you are tired of binary selection of peated/unpeated whisky. || Exceptional whisky || Great whisky
flavour_note: Dark Chocolate, Lemon, Cinnamon, Smoke, Orange, Apple Surprisingly mild in feel. The overall aroma is tightly integrated: spicy-sweet and fruity, combining spiky green leaves and dog roses with autumnal forests, toffee and rich vanilla sauce. The greenness comes to dominate, although the sour notes are tempered by sweet brown butter and a slice of candied fruit. Time reveals more herbal notes, with minty toffee and hints of pastry. Water opens all this up, drying and introducing Speyside notes of the sweetshop, with candy and dried apple rings joined by floral touches. A balance of sweetness, acidity and tannic dryness. Nuts and spice lead, with hazelnuts and almonds joined by bitter walnuts and hot cinnamon. Sweetness builds behind, with candy, barley sugar and sharp candied lemons. The almonds reappear, now sugared, only to disappear amid more citrus, tempered by toffee and fudge spiced with cinnamon, and finally by fruity dark chocolate. Water cools; the smooth sweetness and spice rise, bringing a refreshing bitter note; cream, apple sauce and milk chocolate laced with oak, clove and dark chocolate. Of medium-length, with buttery pastry, warming spice and a thin layer of sharp fruit; a fresh apple pie ready for the oven. The fruit lingers as apple skin, joined by crisp pear.

name: Berry Bros & Rudd Islay Blended Malt
palate: Full, approachable, creamy texture with some sweetness, and the quick reminder of its smoky heritage.
reviews: I thought for the price this is a really nice whisky. I'd suspect its mostly quite young spirits in the mix but still has a decent amount of flavour and finish to be satisfying. Compared to the 'special' releases from the big players at a similar price point I'd take the BBR every time.
flavour_note: Apple, Pear, Smoke, Tar, Cream Full, approachable, creamy texture with some sweetness, and the quick reminder of its smoky heritage. Long lingering peat smoke.

name: Scallywag Speyside Blended Malt
characters: Malt, Orange, Oil, Lemon, Apple, Cinnamon
nose: Sweet and grainy on the nose, with freshly milled malt, porridge made with water, lemon zest, orange peel, redcurrants and a hint of woody spice.
palate: Soft and oily, with some spice on the front of the tongue and developing richness - more porridge, tangy lemon sherbert, lemon bonbons, stewed apples with cinnamon, caraway seeds and a hint of sour fruit.
finish: Medium-length with apples, apple skin, spice and pastry cases.
reviews: Fruity and spicy. Quite a dry taste but overall excellent whisky. I received this as a gift and wouldn’t have bought it myself as I hate dogs! || A bit disappointing. As other reviewers have said, elements of iodine and smoke. Most un-Speyside. A little bitter and short on the palate too. Was expecting much more || Excellent value for money - this is beautiful, full bodied Malt. Worth every penny as this is a thoroughly, thoroughly enjoyable dram || Really excellent and exciting whisky. This is a great Speyside whisky with a character and depth in abundance. A great balance of malt and barley and chocolatey spice. very much recommend. || Nose, Iodine. Palate, smoke and little else. Finish, peat. Nothing like a traditional speyside, no fruits, xmas cake, sherry et al. Very disappointing indeed.
flavour_note: Malt, Orange, Oil, Lemon, Apple, Cinnamon Sweet and grainy on the nose, with freshly milled malt, porridge made with water, lemon zest, orange peel, redcurrants and a hint of woody spice. Soft and oily, with some spice on the front of the tongue and developing richness - more porridge, tangy lemon sherbert, lemon bonbons, stewed apples with cinnamon, caraway seeds and a hint of sour fruit. Medium-length with apples, apple skin, spice and pastry cases.

name: Shackleton Blended Malt
characters: Vanilla, Brioche, Cinnamon, Sultana, Ginger, Pineapple
nose: Vanilla, toffee apple, brioche, Manuka honey and hints of marmalade followed by cinnamon, banana bread and ginger cake.
palate: Treacle toffee, Demerara sugar and sweet sultanas, glazed pineapple, freshly baked crusted bread and mango cake.
finish: Hot mulled wine, praline chocolate and oolong tea with a final whisper of gentle bonfire smoke and crème brûlée.
reviews: Very smooth blended whisky. Nice with a single cube of ice or a quality sparkling water. Never tire of this slightly sweet notes on the initial end. || I generally rotate between three whiskies. Tamnavulin, Laphroaig and Shackleton. I never get tired of Shackleton. I do though get bored at times with the others. || Very nice blended malt.. My current favourite, have had a few bottles of this.. I will be back. Smooth finish.. Ideal with  ice or a splash of water. || Probably best on a cold winteres evening, very pleasant tast with a warm after taste... definitely one for the colder months! || Slight edge of spice initial taste the finishing sweeter notes of tropical fruits. For a blended malt for £18 worth a punt . Well done Richard Patterson on this affordable Scotch.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Brioche, Cinnamon, Sultana, Ginger, Pineapple Vanilla, toffee apple, brioche, Manuka honey and hints of marmalade followed by cinnamon, banana bread and ginger cake. Treacle toffee, Demerara sugar and sweet sultanas, glazed pineapple, freshly baked crusted bread and mango cake. Hot mulled wine, praline chocolate and oolong tea with a final whisper of gentle bonfire smoke and crème brûlée.

name: Blended Malt 197150 Year Old 50th Anniversary
characters: Honey, Wax, Lemon, Sultana, Mango, Pineapple
nose: Shortbread with honey and combs of beeswax. The shortbread becomes more buttery and spread with apple and sultana jam. Spiced vanilla sponge cake pokes out around the edges, balanced by unsweetened whipped cream and savoury vanilla.
palate: Soft fruit leads, with apples and pears joined by barely ripe mango, slightly crunchy pineapple and fruit jelly sweets. Vanilla cream rolls in, followed by a dusting of baking spice. Wax-polished oak sits underneath alongside sponge cake and buttered toast.
finish: Honey and beeswax are joined by sweet candied lemons and more buttered toast.
flavour_note: Honey, Wax, Lemon, Sultana, Mango, Pineapple Shortbread with honey and combs of beeswax. The shortbread becomes more buttery and spread with apple and sultana jam. Spiced vanilla sponge cake pokes out around the edges, balanced by unsweetened whipped cream and savoury vanilla. Soft fruit leads, with apples and pears joined by barely ripe mango, slightly crunchy pineapple and fruit jelly sweets. Vanilla cream rolls in, followed by a dusting of baking spice. Wax-polished oak sits underneath alongside sponge cake and buttered toast. Honey and beeswax are joined by sweet candied lemons and more buttered toast.

characters: Toffee, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Ginger, Cherry, Raisins
reviews: My brother had a bottle of this which I tried at Christmas 2023 I loved it so much, I had bought myself a bottle every year for my Christmas drink And I will be doing it this year as well But this whiskey can be drank any time of the year. So I will instead order 2 this year, 1 for saving for my summer 3025 tipple. || wow... simply wow! || I have tried the Old Perth core range and I have to say, for a cask strength whisky it is amazing!! Super easy to drink and such complex tasting notes on the palate. Beautiful dram and 10/10 recommend! || Delicious Dram! i love the toffee and dried fruit tasting notes, perfect dram for this winter weather
flavour_note: Toffee, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Ginger, Cherry, Raisins

name: Compass Box The Peat MonsterGlass Set
Big Peat Blended Malt Christmas Edition
