name: Rock Island 10 Year Old
reviews: Refined and delicious. The maritime style is apparent but the smokey peated qualities shine through marvellously || Wow what a Malt. really does take you to the coast - lots of salt / pepper / smokey sweetness
flavour_note: Smoke, Orange, Salt (powder), Oak

name: Rock Island
characters: Sage, Rosemary, Black Pepper, Liquorice root, Brine, Honey
nose: As fresh and invigorating as a walk on the seafront. Briney, cough sweets, liquorice, and fresh herbs (sage and rosemary).
palate: Richer than expected, with warming notes of black pepper, sea salt and ozone, as well as a hint of honeyed fruit. Good weight.
finish: The well-balanced peat acts as a seabreak to the subtle but welcome fruit.
reviews: Sweet smoke with a long finish. Not a light dram but surprisingly sweet at the end. || Quite unique but nothing special about this one. I don't regret buying it but wouldn't buy it again, however I am still inclined to try the more expensive age-labeled ones due to the "uniqueness" of this brand.
flavour_note: Sage, Rosemary, Black Pepper, Liquorice root, Brine, Honey As fresh and invigorating as a walk on the seafront. Briney, cough sweets, liquorice, and fresh herbs (sage and rosemary). Richer than expected, with warming notes of black pepper, sea salt and ozone, as well as a hint of honeyed fruit. Good weight. The well-balanced peat acts as a seabreak to the subtle but welcome fruit.

name: King of Trees Highland 10 Year OldWhisky Works
flavour_note: Apple, Pear, Vanilla, Nutmeg, Oak

name: Compass Box Juveniles
characters: Pear, Vanilla, Mixed Herb, Biscuits, Lemon
reviews: Very poor - mostly Clynelish but without any cask influence. You get old and stale whisky.. notice how the 5* reviews do not tell you what it actually tastes like. || This is an awesome CB release. Much more vivid fresh fruits and nicer flavour profile integration than Spice tree and just shy of Phenomenology in overall quality. It is probably an younger blend than Phenomenology. A must buy when on sale. || Excellent. Bought a couple of compass box before, but this really is top notch. || Delicate on the nose, very smooth with initial sweetness but dry, grassy finish. Much more complex and subtle flavour than you'd expect and very enjoyable. One of my favourite Class Box releases.
flavour_note: Pear, Vanilla, Mixed Herb, Biscuits, Lemon

name: Cladach Blended MaltSpecial Releases 2018
characters: Brine, Smoke, Apple, Black Pepper, Orange, Lemon
nose: Pink shrimp sweets and leather to start, with smoke slowly building behind. Fresh sea air and crashing waves sit alongside earthy peat and maritime-tinged smoke. Meaty barbecue notes develop.
palate: Peat leads but is quickly pushed to the back. The whisky is built around a sweet centre of boiled sweets and apple sauce, surrounded by salt and freshly-ground black pepper. A tingle of sherbet leads to zesty waxed lemons and sweet orange.
finish: Sweet peat and grass with a touch of char.
reviews: Volcanic blended malt with a salty, seaweed start and a long smoky finish || It’s hard to argue with the tasting notes above. And do not worry about this being a blend - it is a superb dram. The thing that really got me, was the smoothness. At 57% my throat should have been tingling... but no. No water required for this beauty. A rare sight in any bar so had to try it.... and was not disappointed. Absolutely stunning.
flavour_note: Brine, Smoke, Apple, Black Pepper, Orange, Lemon Pink shrimp sweets and leather to start, with smoke slowly building behind. Fresh sea air and crashing waves sit alongside earthy peat and maritime-tinged smoke. Meaty barbecue notes develop. Peat leads but is quickly pushed to the back. The whisky is built around a sweet centre of boiled sweets and apple sauce, surrounded by salt and freshly-ground black pepper. A tingle of sherbet leads to zesty waxed lemons and sweet orange. Sweet peat and grass with a touch of char.

name: Compass Box Flaming Heart2018 Edition Magnum
characters: Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Dried Fruit, Orange, Clove, Smoke
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Dried Fruit, Orange, Clove, Smoke

name: Speyside Region 197343 Year Old Whisky Agency for TWE
nose: Spiced brioche, brown sugar and rich lardy cake. Cinnamon buns and iced Danish pastries with a cherry on the top. Fruit jelly notes develop – lemon, lime and pineapple – with a background of old, wax-polished oak tables. Meatier notes slowly emerge, balanced by sugar flowers, candied lemon and sweet whipped cream.
palate: Creamily textured, with lightly spiced egg-custard tarts leading into old Chartreuse, spiced sponge cake and butter cream – the herbal notes float around on top, while underneath sit piles of cakes and oaty biscuits. In between are fruity boiled sweets, barley sugar and herbal throat sweets. Tarte tatin notes develop, softly spiced and drenched with butter.
finish: Apple sauce and buttered toast. Toasted, spiced, fruit loaf develops. Apple sweets and cream remain.
reviews: Lucky enough to have tried this exceptional whisky recently, and must say for it to be blended, it is far superior to most 40+year single malts I have tried over the years. A full 10/10 to whomever is responsible for this blend. Superb. || Amazing dram. Complexity, waxiness, citrus fruits, tropical fruits, polish and an amazing, long finish || Fantastic dram, elegant and complex – a real stunner. || Stunning – another Speyside that hits every mark. || Really great stuff, as good or better than most of the other 73s I have tasted and this one is actually more reasonably priced than most. Get it while you can.
flavour_note: Spiced brioche, brown sugar and rich lardy cake. Cinnamon buns and iced Danish pastries with a cherry on the top. Fruit jelly notes develop – lemon, lime and pineapple – with a background of old, wax-polished oak tables. Meatier notes slowly emerge, balanced by sugar flowers, candied lemon and sweet whipped cream. Creamily textured, with lightly spiced egg-custard tarts leading into old Chartreuse, spiced sponge cake and butter cream – the herbal notes float around on top, while underneath sit piles of cakes and oaty biscuits. In between are fruity boiled sweets, barley sugar and herbal throat sweets. Tarte tatin notes develop, softly spiced and drenched with butter. Apple sauce and buttered toast. Toasted, spiced, fruit loaf develops. Apple sweets and cream remain.

name: Berry Bros & Rudd Peated Cask Matured Blended Malt
palate: A fruity sweetness introduces the soft peaty character. Well balanced to perfection.
flavour_note: Smoke, Apple, Pear, Apricot A fruity sweetness introduces the soft peaty character. Well balanced to perfection. Mid-long, deliciously peated.

name: The Gauldrons Batch 1
nose: A dry saltiness with sweet cereal and a late hint of gentle peat smoke.
palate: Initially dry (beachy and maritime) warming to crunched sugar, barley and oak.
finish: Warmingly spiced, bringing puffs of smoke and rock pools with a dark sugar sweetness.
reviews: Single Cask Single Malts married together to create one of the most unique and wonderful drams I have had in a while. As I work in the industry I have tried my fair share of whisky and every so often you come across one that stands out, this is one of them. Rich and baked biscuit nose then delicate smoke and caramel on the palate.
flavour_note: A dry saltiness with sweet cereal and a late hint of gentle peat smoke. Initially dry (beachy and maritime) warming to crunched sugar, barley and oak. Warmingly spiced, bringing puffs of smoke and rock pools with a dark sugar sweetness.

name: The EpicureanDouglas Laing
characters: Mixed Herb, Banana, Leaves, Lemon, Cream
nose: Citrus fruit and green banana with classic Lowland meadow hints and creamy touches.
palate: Juicy lemon and melon with sweet cream and soft spice.
finish: Lemon zest, spice and leafy herbs.
reviews: one of the best whiskies I've ever bought. A perfect Lowland mix of fresh fruity flavours with heavy vanilla oak . I loved every drop . can't recommend it enough
flavour_note: Mixed Herb, Banana, Leaves, Lemon, Cream Citrus fruit and green banana with classic Lowland meadow hints and creamy touches. Juicy lemon and melon with sweet cream and soft spice. Lemon zest, spice and leafy herbs.

name: Yula 20 Year OldChapter One Douglas Laing
Wemyss Malts Spice King
characters: Black Pepper, Cinnamon, Orange, Apple, Malt, Oak
flavour_note: Black Pepper, Cinnamon, Orange, Apple, Malt, Oak

name: Wemyss Malts The Hive
reviews: A nice dram

name: Highland Journey
characters: Lemon, Cinnamon, Black Pepper, Vanilla, Heather, Almond
reviews: WOW. A real surprise.So smooth with a wonderful after taste that excites the senses for a long time after it has been consumed. To be shared only with those who appreciate transformation in a glass.
flavour_note: Lemon, Cinnamon, Black Pepper, Vanilla, Heather, Almond

name: Timorous Beastie Highland Blended Malt
nose: Fresh and appley, with barley (malted and not), sweet butter and lemon. Some sour apple and sweet pear drop sneak in around the sides.
palate: Oily, with more butter and candied fruit. Some icing sugar and butter cream sweetness appear, with darkly sweet raisins and soft brown sugar.
finish: Gentle spice, a pinch of orchard fruit and some dark sugar notes.
reviews: This is a fabulous malt with a huge amount of complexity and interest. A great balance of sweetness and spice. Hugely recommend. || Pale gold in colour then sweet honey on the tongue. Abide a while and the complex spiceyness almost explodes! Definitely not Timourous, and a pure delight for our Burn’s Fest !! || Delicious, easy to drink with a lovely after taste. || Great blend - taste is an iffy thing for sure but to give my take on things I rate Lagavulin 16 year old as my single malt of choice followed by 10 year old laphroaig and then other similar single malts BUT I find Monkey Shoulder blended malt to be a great taste and the best buy for the money that I have yet to try - all this said I got the Timorous Beastie for Christmas and each time I try an ounce or so, neat and at room temperature, I am more impressed - and the bottle is positively overwhelming to see on my whisky shelf - I will definitely buy another, || Simply Devine! A great highland Malt and a new favourite for sure
flavour_note: Apple, Malt, Butter, Lemon, Raisins Fresh and appley, with barley (malted and not), sweet butter and lemon. Some sour apple and sweet pear drop sneak in around the sides. Oily, with more butter and candied fruit. Some icing sugar and butter cream sweetness appear, with darkly sweet raisins and soft brown sugar. Gentle spice, a pinch of orchard fruit and some dark sugar notes.

name: Highland Harvest7 Casks Organic Blended Malt Whisky
flavour_note: Peach, Apple, Malt, Grass

name: Blue Hanger 9th Release
reviews: A benchmark for blended (vatted) malts - elegant and very well balanced, a harmonious blend of sherried and peated aromas. || Wow. Just tried a sample bottle of this. A very very nice sippin Whisky with subtle peaty taste. No smokiness and very smooth. No real afterburn and leaves you wanting more. It is a slightly better version of,and similar to, the Laddie ten. I will certainly be buying a full bottle of this.

name: The Last Vatted MaltCompass Box
reviews: The best scotch I have, the best of my two favorite regions, in one bottle. There is a lot going on with this scotch, I’m no expert, however I taste about 20 different flavours with a peat smoke finish. I own about 40 bottles, this and Johnny Walker Green are my only blends. I will try more Compass Box for sure.

name: Shackleton's DiscoveryMackinlay's Rare Old Highland Malt
reviews: I bought 3 of these back in 2014. I took one to Antarctica in 2015, where my brother and I opened a bottle on the Antarctic Peninsular, 100 years after Shackleton was last there. One is still unopened and will stay that way. The other is used for special occasions. I top it up from the standard bottles that are still available on sale. A better whiskey than I imagined for a blend. Watch Richard Patterson on YouTube where he tells you how to drink it and it'll change your whisky drinking technique for life. I give it 5 stars because of the history. Just drinking it takes me back 100 years. || A great re-creation, smooth, full flavor. Have been saving 3 bottles for a special occasion, but incredibly, was able to have a couple of drams this spring when I was in Punta Arenas, Chile (Patagonia/Straits of Magellan) in the Shackleton Bar, Hotel Jos? Nogueira. History at two levels! Excellent taste and flavor. || awesome, Macallan 18yr old and this are unbeatable, Shackleton has been one of my motivational hero's so ive had to drink 5 bottles after an endurance event, still have 2 left. best time to drink it is when it snows and in front of an outdoor fire pit || Very good. I was expecting this to not be very good value, given the history attached to the whisky creation and the outstanding blended malts in this price bracket that it would compete with. Very balanced, integrated and complex with a hot finish. || Totally not at all like the one at Channing's. If you ever get the chance to actually taste the real thing , there is NO comparing as to the ultimate smoothness and the lasting peaty of the original. I guess I will have to go back to Scotland...

name: Compass Box Peat Monster Cask Strength
characters: Peat smoke, Vanilla, Cinnamon, Lemon, Orange
flavour_note: Peat smoke, Vanilla, Cinnamon, Lemon, Orange

name: Chivas Century Of Malts
reviews: I had a bottle of this when it first came out some twenty years ago and loved it then. The little booklet it came with written by none other than Jim Murray was also fun. Was lucky enough to find another bottle last year gathering dust on a shelf here in Tokyo for 10,000 (£70 or $90). I drink from it sparingly, but always enjoy the experience. Unsurprisingly there's a lot going on in the glass and I find different notes with each sip. It always surprises me how harmoniously this vatted malt is, and I kind of dig the fact that I've technically drunk the distillate of all 100 distilleries, especially ones like Banff, Brechin/North Port, Dallas Dhu, Glen Albyn, Glen Mhor, Kinclaith, Ladyburn etc which are either impossible to find or prohibitively expensive if you can. Unfortunately this is the last glass (until I find another steal). Slainte. || Have been bought this as a Christmas present,a Wonderfull drinking experience,thankyou son! || I love this whisky and the cheeky way you can say you have tasted almost all the singlemalts! || hi I purchased a few bottles at the time and tried one, delicious!!still have a few bottles that I might sell one day for the right price || It is ok...nose just a confused mess, but the pallet is nice, finish is short and sweet...not bad, but not worth the price ransom ebayers want for it. 84/100

name: Sheep Dip Blended Malt
nose: Delicate and refined. Soft sensual floral notes arise in perfect harmony supported by an attractive array of complex fruit flavours. Melon, pear and orange with a hint of almonds conclude this profusion of charming nuances.
reviews: I very much enjoy sheep dip. I love the hat tip to days long gone. Only down side is getting my hands on a bottle or two. || I have to say i was quite taken with this one, woody and earthy with toffee and nutmeg on the nose. hints of Caol Ila on the palate, a little smoke and Islay dampness, just a mere drop of H2o will do it good || Excellent blended malt || One of the best I have ever bought || Excellent! Smokey, peaty, smooth; everything I want from a whiskey!
flavour_note: Delicate and refined. Soft sensual floral notes arise in perfect harmony supported by an attractive array of complex fruit flavours. Melon, pear and orange with a hint of almonds conclude this profusion of charming nuances.

name: Serendipity 12 Year Old
reviews: I can confirm this was an accident as I was working at the Glenmorangie bottling plant at the time, and they also bottle Glen Moray, Ardbeg amongst others. Basically there was some of one product still in the vats when the other had been started, therefore mixing both. Only option is to bottle it so it doesn''t surprise me its happened before and im sure it wasn''t a stunt as the bottles were sold for a very fair price in the factory shop only (as far as I knew) hope this clears up any mysteries || Ive a bottle half empty and one unopened. Its delightful || I've tasted it and it is heavenly. I || "Seriously though.. how would Glen Moray even end up close to an Ardbeg vat?" ... from the time when Glen Moray and Ardbeg had the same owner and were bottled in the same plant.Probably originally intended to be a last batch of the Ardbeg 17yo. Whether accidental or deliberate, I like the result a lot. 40% and lowish peat will disappoint the peatheads. But if you are just sitting with a glass of this on its own, it is a lovely, complex and quite gentle dram. || Seriously though.. how would Glen Moray even end up close to an Ardbeg vat?

name: Glenleven 12 Year OldBot.1980s
reviews: I miss this scotch very much. Last time I was able to buy it was maybe 15 years ago. Perhaps the best I have ever had.

name: Famous Grouse 30 Year Old
reviews: This is very dark, concentrated and delicious. For me, it may be a bit much at times, so I find myself adding a few drops to round up a relatively younger, more vibrant whiskey, such as the Glenlivet Archive 21 yo. If you happen to have both on hand, I encourage you to give it a try, it`s quite spectacular. || Karl, Dave and Amy Locke just returned from Scotch Distillery tour of Scotland. We went to dozens of distilleries. Probably, one of the finest whiskys that we have ever tasted is the Famous Grouse 30 year. We brought 4 bottles home with us. We have just completed an order for 6 more bottles from the Whisky Exchange. We received our order within a week.

name: Famous Grouse 198912 Year Old
characters: Smoke, Dried Fruit, Milk Chocolate, Orange, Raisins
flavour_note: Smoke, Dried Fruit, Milk Chocolate, Orange, Raisins

name: Jameson 23 Year Old Small BatchExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Raisins, White Pepper, Toffee, Apple, Pear, Cashew
nose: Apples, pears and unripe nectarines leading vanilla cream, polished oak and spiced shortbread. Exotic notes of sour physalis and sweet papaya build, joined by more shortbread and a slice of lemon drizzle cake.
palate: Rich and oily spirit with toffee and vanilla cream chased by layers of fruit: sour apples and unripe pears, crisp sweet green apples and just-ripe pears, green mango, papaya, pineapple and gummi bears. Spiced sponge cake and light fruitcake develops along with wax-polished oak and hints of fruity dark chocolate.
finish: Spicy oak slowly fades to leave aniseed balls, apple sauce and crisp pear.
flavour_note: Raisins, White Pepper, Toffee, Apple, Pear, Cashew Apples, pears and unripe nectarines leading vanilla cream, polished oak and spiced shortbread. Exotic notes of sour physalis and sweet papaya build, joined by more shortbread and a slice of lemon drizzle cake. Rich and oily spirit with toffee and vanilla cream chased by layers of fruit: sour apples and unripe pears, crisp sweet green apples and just-ripe pears, green mango, papaya, pineapple and gummi bears. Spiced sponge cake and light fruitcake develops along with wax-polished oak and hints of fruity dark chocolate. Spicy oak slowly fades to leave aniseed balls, apple sauce and crisp pear.

name: Midleton Very RareBot.2025
characters: Toffee, Caramel, Apple, Lavender, Mint, White Pepper
flavour_note: Toffee, Caramel, Apple, Lavender, Mint, White Pepper

name: Connemara Peated Irish Whiskey
nose: Okay, well the smoke will not go unnoticed on the palate, but it is so clean, and surrounded by floral sweetness, that to compare it to a Scottish whisky would not quite be fair (to either). Peated barley at the heart of the flavours, grassy, and increasingly drying. Oak and almonds.
finish: A unique peated whiskey experience. Very drinkable, even quaff-able, with sweetness, and an interesting summer weeds type of presence. And plenty of peat, but don't expect a peat beast; this is driving-through-the-country window-seat-peat.
reviews: Lucky enough to have seen a bottle in a ferry duty-free. So glad to have enjoyed some of its most enjoyable flavours. || Very good single malt whiskey !its smoky touch of Irish peat! it lacks a little power around 48°! I love it ! || I have been a malt fan for many of my 80 years, the single malt that I like the best is Connemara peated ,I brought my first bottle while staying near Kilkee ,county Clare, fortunately for me I have found a supplier near to me in Cornwall, so I can always smile !! || Great peaty whiskey from Ireland. || No, my usual drink is Tollamore Dew! But I’m interested in trying this. Thank You
flavour_note: Honeysuckle, Smoke, Vanilla, Apple Okay, well the smoke will not go unnoticed on the palate, but it is so clean, and surrounded by floral sweetness, that to compare it to a Scottish whisky would not quite be fair (to either). Peated barley at the heart of the flavours, grassy, and increasingly drying. Oak and almonds. A unique peated whiskey experience. Very drinkable, even quaff-able, with sweetness, and an interesting summer weeds type of presence. And plenty of peat, but don't expect a peat beast; this is driving-through-the-country window-seat-peat.

name: Jameson Crested
reviews: Yes it's delicious. Smooth and light || Just had it in Dublin on the Jameson tour. Brought a bottle back with me. Love it. Very smooth. || Love this stuff. Had it first time on a trip to Ireland and it is now my favorite whiskey. Pair that with the cheap price and you got a happy whiskey drink

name: Green Spot
nose: Toffee and malt dominate, but still rather lean and clean, with a smattering of apple and pear.
palate: Soft on the palate, with chewy maltiness, and gentle fruit.
finish: Quite short, but lovely balance between the fruit and malt.
reviews: Excellent whiskey tried it on holiday and was delighted with it and I'm scottish || Incredible Smooth drink || Great whiskey, would highly recommend || Top notch, very smooth, only redbreast can be better || I started my whiskey journey with the well known Irish brands but then moved to Scotch and found myself liking the smoky and peaty affairs which was my preference.. Seen this as a recommendation so I thought I'd try it and boy, what a surprise. Crisp green apples on the nose also on initial tasting moving to a toffee/bourbon/minty affair smoothing out to vanilla. Finish is quite short for me, but that's not a minus. My new favourite!
flavour_note: Malt, Toffee, Apple, Pear Toffee and malt dominate, but still rather lean and clean, with a smattering of apple and pear. Soft on the palate, with chewy maltiness, and gentle fruit. Quite short, but lovely balance between the fruit and malt.

name: Jameson Black Barrel
characters: Nutmeg, Dried Fruit, Oak, Malt, Honey, Apple
nose: Soft barrel-char aromas, along with sweet barley and cereal.
palate: Very soft and smooth. Subtle spiciness and barrel char comes through, along with fresh fruitiness.
reviews: If I could give,I would give 3,8 stars out of 5. It's character is hmmm... Round and smooth. If you like whisky with strong flavours,this is not for you,but if you like whisky without strong taste,this is for you. || Very nice and fresh, long glass with ice & giger ale. South America summer! || A very nice sweet fruity Irish profile. This New Years we did a comparison tasting of bushmills, powers red label, green spot, Jamesons black barrel, yellow spot and redbreast 12. This was solidly right in the middle of the pack. Not as good as. Ice as yellow spot or redbreast but a great value. || On the nose I get raisins, dates ,sweet Sherry & oak . Definitely it’s spent most of its time in Sherry barrels, it’s got just enough burn it’s not as smooth as I would have liked it’s quite young maybe 4- 5 years old , but the finish is long and enjoyable. Definitely Jameson’s are tapping into the Bourbon market. And you know what!! it reminds me of Black Bush. Which is also Sherry cask . And them guys have been producing that stuff for ever. I’m tempted to get a bottle of Black Bush to compare, but from my memory I seem to think Black Bush is a little more refined I could be wrong though. but I do know it’s more affordable but probably not as popular right now. || Feck its good
flavour_note: Nutmeg, Dried Fruit, Oak, Malt, Honey, Apple Soft barrel-char aromas, along with sweet barley and cereal. Very soft and smooth. Subtle spiciness and barrel char comes through, along with fresh fruitiness. Smooth and balanced.

name: Sexton Single Malt Irish Whiskey
reviews: As an Ulsterman in exile I have been a Bushmills fan for most of my adult life(72), always been a fan of Black Bush and the matured variations but this liquid amber has stolen the show for me. || I tried this in an advent calendar. It is true that it is very smooth. However, some mention its sweetness, which, as a Speyside lover, I have not detected. I enjoy both Dailuaine, as well as Talisker - both in their own ways quite character-full - and that is what I find lacking in this sample. || Tried this over ice. A large one of course. As described. A lovely wee dram. Alex H, You are right about the bottle :) || Pleasantly surprised. I rather enjoy Peat Whiskey however this one has been really enjoyable. Excellent over ice or a splash of water. Extremely smooth. A lovely sweet honey taste on the end. Coming around the £30 this is definitely value for money. My only gripe is bottle design it's not very friendly in pouring but that is me being critical. || Very nice smooth Irish malt. The Best !

name: Redbreast 12 Year Old
reviews: Back again for another bottle of this very special Irish single pot still whiskey. I've been a dedicated follower of Scottish single malts for over 40 years. I have my favourites but decided to branch out and try the single pot still whiskeys. I'm delighted I did. I now have a range of the 'Spot' whiskeys, all delightful but the 12 year old Redbreast stands out. A very approachable and easy to drink whiskey. Received with the usual care and efficiency I have come to expect from TWE over many years.

name: Powers Irish Rye
characters: Orange, White Pepper, Cherry, Ginger, Honey, Vanilla
reviews: I've tried a few American and Canadian rye whiskies now, my favourite being Sazerac. Powers' Irish Rye doesn't seem inferior in comparison to any of them, is quite drinkable, nice and spicy, but from my experience the only definitive way to compare is to have a few of them on the go and blind taste them, which I've done with some Single Pot Still whiskies. I'd definitely buy this again || On the flavour to price ratio this is a win || As I'm writing this review, I'm sipping a glass of Jack Daniel's Rye ( I bought at Duty-Free ( U.S.) in January,2024 ).Rye is a U.S. ( and Canadian ) classic whiskey. Now, JD is new to the Rye Business ( and not near close to a No.1 Rye ).Powers Rye is a very poor Rye example ..insipid/weak...Ireland Calling ! || A light-bodied rye that is actually quite delicate and intricate in flavour as the charred-cask effect is not noticeable, unlike in US rye whiskies. A welcome addition to the Powers range, I would definitely buy this again || Well up to the best of American rye whiskys
flavour_note: Orange, White Pepper, Cherry, Ginger, Honey, Vanilla

reviews: It's a young whisky. However, there are a lot of things to like about it. The nose is floral honey, vanilla and raisin for me. The taste is similar. I think with time this could be phenomenal. Already worth getting to try but this more aged is a very exciting prospect

name: Redbreast 19 Year OldOloroso Sherry Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cherry, Vanilla, Prunes, Dark Chocolate, Honey, Oak
nose: Weighty and rich with layers of fruit: plump sultanas, dried apricots and baked apples leading to cherries and berries. Pot-still spice and green leaves hide underneath along with cinder toffee and sandalwood.
palate: Intense fruit to start, wrapped in a spicy oak overcoat. Apples and pears with a touch of mango and pineapple cake, all followed by sultanas and raisins. Baking spice and toffee notes build.
reviews: Not as smooth as the 21 year old, but still a great whisky. Exceedingly fast shipping! || 12 year old Irish whiskey with toasted oak and sherry undertones. It makes me so happy.
flavour_note: Cherry, Vanilla, Prunes, Dark Chocolate, Honey, Oak Weighty and rich with layers of fruit: plump sultanas, dried apricots and baked apples leading to cherries and berries. Pot-still spice and green leaves hide underneath along with cinder toffee and sandalwood. Intense fruit to start, wrapped in a spicy oak overcoat. Apples and pears with a touch of mango and pineapple cake, all followed by sultanas and raisins. Baking spice and toffee notes build. Lingering fruit and spice.

Very drinkable with a splash of water or a single cube of ice. A terrific everyday whiskey at a reasonable price. I would recommend it to others.

name: Green Spot Leoville Barton Bordeaux Finish
characters: Apple, Melon, Clove, Nutmeg, Custard, Raspberry
nose: Fresh apples, warming berry fruit, woody spice, aromas of egg custard and crème brûlée, along with rose petals and nutmeg.
palate: Fresh and fruity initially, with refreshing fruity notes of green apple, greengage, melon and soft notes of raspberry, then spicier notes take over – clove and nutmeg.
finish: The soft red fruits balance well with the firmer, spicier notes.
reviews: This is a beautiful whiskey fruity and smooth. Highly recommended. || One of my favourites || Green Spot is my go to drink. But saying that this is not for me – there's too much vanilla which makes it too sweet. || Superb whiskey, great taste. One of the best irish whiskeys I’ve had.
flavour_note: Apple, Melon, Clove, Nutmeg, Custard, Raspberry Fresh apples, warming berry fruit, woody spice, aromas of egg custard and crème brûlée, along with rose petals and nutmeg. Fresh and fruity initially, with refreshing fruity notes of green apple, greengage, melon and soft notes of raspberry, then spicier notes take over – clove and nutmeg. The soft red fruits balance well with the firmer, spicier notes.

It’s my Sunday night go to. || Just received my third bottle of Bushmills 16 year old from TWE. I keep coming back and the whiskey never fails to enchant. I'll leave the florid descriptions to others. Suffice to say, as a malt drinker of over 40 years, this whiskey remains one of my top four favourites.

flavour_note: Honey, Caramel, Apple, Raisins, Vanilla, Pear

name: Redbreast Lustau Edition
characters: Marzipan, Liquorice root, Sherry, Prunes, Figs
nose: Rich infusion of dark fruits, prunes, dates and figs with liquorice, marzipan, toasted oak and Redbreast spices.
finish: Endless. Sweetness and pot-still spices endure while oloroso sherry and Spanish oak have the last word.
reviews: At the price point this is simply outstanding. You could easily break the £100 mark and find far worse. More excellent stuff from Redbreast || I had bottle bought me for Birthday it’s absolutely lovely only problem didn’t last long enough lol . I Recommend to everyone one who loves whiskey. || Very smooth, sweet but not overpowering sweetness, nice cherry hint || Very smooth. No after bite. I can drink this product without any problems. || Remember the first time you sampled Redbreast (neat - obviously)? That first encounter with one of the finest expressions of the Irish pot still whiskey tradition lives long in the memory. There's the loving, silken mouthfeel as you roll it around as if your tongue, teeth and gums have encountered the rays of the evening sun somehow miraculously transmuted into a warming, golden liquid. Then comes the flavour which starts at the front of the mouth with hints of cinder toffee, candied peel and parma violets which segues as that first mouthful is slowly swallowed into walnuts and Dutch tobacco. Then the aftermath which is redolent of a walk through an orange grove just as the fruits are landing in the basket. And the sheer lusciousness of the experience as the sunshine slides into the soul and spreads out again, bringing joy and radiance to you and your companions. Remember what drinking Redbreast is like? Well, Redbreast Lustau edition is exactly like that. Only better.
flavour_note: Marzipan, Liquorice root, Sherry, Prunes, Figs Rich infusion of dark fruits, prunes, dates and figs with liquorice, marzipan, toasted oak and Redbreast spices. Endless. Sweetness and pot-still spices endure while oloroso sherry and Spanish oak have the last word.

name: Powers John's Lane 12 Year OldSingle Pot Still
nose: Appealingly heady nose of candied orange peel and pot pourri - very fragrant and aromatic, with lightness of touch.
palate: The aromatic fruit continues on to the palate, with toasty spice. Good texture and balance.
finish: The light fruit makes way for the biscuity malt and subtle cinnamon-tinged spice.
reviews:
Lovely whiskey. As expected it is very similar to Redbreast 12 but at 46% has a bit more depth. They say it has more bourbon aged whiskey and that fits with the spice on the palate. This is a keeper. || Absolutely outstanding.  Love it || Absolutely the best Irish whiskey I’ve tried to date.
Much better than Red Breast or Green Spot.
Powers Gold is a strong runner up. || Chunky, rustic, real. || Delicious whiskey with long lasting, complex aftertones  of spice and oak. My absolute favourite. Richer than a Redbreast with a satisfying heat.
flavour_note: Orange, Toast, Biscuits, Cinnamon Appealingly heady nose of candied orange peel and pot pourri - very fragrant and aromatic, with lightness of touch. The aromatic fruit continues on to the palate, with toasty spice. Good texture and balance. The light fruit makes way for the biscuity malt and subtle cinnamon-tinged spice.

name: Tyrconnell Single Malt
reviews: Bought this on a whim to share with some colleagues at a business event. Absolutely great decision, superbly smooth, great barrel character, some nice fruit notes. Great value || Really nice experience, I will buy it again || I like the golden appearance. Light , sweet taste. Honey comes to mind first. Very smooth , no harsh afterburner. I would recommend it for a great sip after work. || I got this as a gift and it was a bit of a revelation. Lovely and smooth, lots of complexity and for once, I can actually detect almost everything the tasting notes here actually mention (or maybe the power of suggestion is stronger here). My mind has been opened and I will be buying this again for sure. For the price, it's great value.

name: Jameson 22 Year Old Small BatchExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Milk Chocolate, Hazelnut, Apple, Mango, Nutmeg, Vanilla
nose: Chocolate dipped honeycomb with orange zest, charred oak and vanilla spice. Dried apricots with hints of ginger and nutmeg add to the array of aromas.
palate: More cooked white fruits, mango jam, papaya, dried apricots, golden sultanas, crème caramel, and chocolate fudge brownies with whipped cream. That nuttiness re-emerges with marzipan, nutmeg and ground ginger, green coffee beans, and a drop of imperial stout. The bourbon and sherry casks bring a great sense of richness and texture but they don’t overwhelm the fruity pot still whiskey at the core of the blend. Very nicely done.
finish: Long and oily with an earthiness that keeps the sweeter notes in balance. The tropical fruits come back at the end accompanied by warming spices.
flavour_note: Milk Chocolate, Hazelnut, Apple, Mango, Nutmeg, Vanilla Chocolate dipped honeycomb with orange zest, charred oak and vanilla spice. Dried apricots with hints of ginger and nutmeg add to the array of aromas. More cooked white fruits, mango jam, papaya, dried apricots, golden sultanas, crème caramel, and chocolate fudge brownies with whipped cream. That nuttiness re-emerges with marzipan, nutmeg and ground ginger, green coffee beans, and a drop of imperial stout. The bourbon and sherry casks bring a great sense of richness and texture but they don’t overwhelm the fruity pot still whiskey at the core of the blend. Very nicely done. Long and oily with an earthiness that keeps the sweeter notes in balance. The tropical fruits come back at the end accompanied by warming spices.

name: Green Spot Chateau Montelena Zinfandel Finish
nose: Crisp oak combines with the soft sweetness of vanilla, white chocolate and marshmallow, balanced with signature Green Spot red apples and ripe pears, along with pomegranate, cranberries and maraschino cherries, the contribution of the wine cask
palate: Sweet mouth coating takes on a dry note thanks to the effect of the wine cask. Pot still spices subside with zesty citrus leading to ripe orchard fruit and red berries. A touch of marzipan and toasted oak add to the complexity
reviews: A gift from Dublin when my wife returned recently. I had never tried a Greenspot whiskey before. I have to say I am very impressed with this one. Great spicy flavours, very smooth and extremely easy to drink. I will be adding this to my list of favourites! || I bought a bottle after reading the reviews and I’m slightly disappointed with it. I thought it would be as good as the Redbreast Single Pot Still 12 years old. But I’m glad I bought it as a part of my collection. || I like the standard Green Spot and was keen to see if this finish added anything. It did. This version is even better and I’d recommend it, particularly to people who have maybe tried one or two Irish whiskies but didn’t find something in them to encourage them to try more || An extremely good irish. Not harsh in the nose, but creamy and almost butterscotchy if that can be a word. The cream is there on the pallate. Easy drinking, yes yes yes.
flavour_note: Crisp oak combines with the soft sweetness of vanilla, white chocolate and marshmallow, balanced with signature Green Spot red apples and ripe pears, along with pomegranate, cranberries and maraschino cherries, the contribution of the wine cask Sweet mouth coating takes on a dry note thanks to the effect of the wine cask. Pot still spices subside with zesty citrus leading to ripe orchard fruit and red berries. A touch of marzipan and toasted oak add to the complexity

name: Glendalough Double Barrel Single Grain
nose: Slight but undoubtedly rich with dark fruit; cherry, raisin, fig (with Christmas pudding notes on the nose for those lucky enough to know what that is) along with floral lemongrass and a touch of nutmeg.
palate: Sweet and creamy on the palate, with butterscotch, honey and peppercorn bringing along sweet Bourbon Cask notes with dried fruit returning through notes of maraschino cherries and a pinch of brown sugar.
finish: Lingering notes of ginger spices with a faint glimmer of almond to end a complex Irish Whiskey from start to finish.
reviews: Low in vanilla compared with what you'd expect from bourbon barrels but otherwise the description is accurate and for the money this is a surprisingly complex and extremly enjoyable whiskey. Sweetness level is just right too. 5 stars for a £30 whiskey. || Dry tasting but has a sweet aftertaste. Great body and flavour || This is a fantastic whiskey, smell and taste very typical of pot still whiskies so if you're a fan this will not disappoint. For the price you pay this is a steal! || Good whisky for the money. Nothing special or extraordinary, smooth ant definitely not Irish taste. || Smooth and sweet, full and friendly this is a fantastic friend! Description of the nose, palate and finish are quite accurate.
flavour_note: Slight but undoubtedly rich with dark fruit; cherry, raisin, fig (with Christmas pudding notes on the nose for those lucky enough to know what that is) along with floral lemongrass and a touch of nutmeg. Sweet and creamy on the palate, with butterscotch, honey and peppercorn bringing along sweet Bourbon Cask notes with dried fruit returning through notes of maraschino cherries and a pinch of brown sugar. Lingering notes of ginger spices with a faint glimmer of almond to end a complex Irish Whiskey from start to finish.

name: Teeling Single Grain Whiskey
characters: Toffee, Leaves, Mixed Herb, Cinnamon, Butter, Wine
nose: Meaty and sweet with bitter tannins, sweet toffee, fudge, green leaves, dried mixed herbs dark chocolate, marmalade and anise.
palate: Toffee, spice (cinnamon and nutmeg), orchard fruit, grape skin, polished oak and butterscotch.
finish: Grape skin and red wine tannic touches, with spiced butter and shortbread.
reviews: Really enjoyed this Irish single grain whisky, I would go as far to say one of the best single grain whiskies I've ever had, and adding water only helps elevate the experience. Certainly helps being a hight alcoholic strength and non-chill filtered, solid 4.5 stars. || Yes I tried Teeling Single Grain Whiskey and would say one of the best whiskeys I ever tasted, it's fantastic || Excellent Irish Whiskey. As smooth as it gets! || Loved this. || A first class grain whiskey. Often thought of as the poor relative of the single malt but only fully appreciated when tasted. My first bottle will soon need replacing. Give it a go!
flavour_note: Toffee, Leaves, Mixed Herb, Cinnamon, Butter, Wine Meaty and sweet with bitter tannins, sweet toffee, fudge, green leaves, dried mixed herbs dark chocolate, marmalade and anise. Toffee, spice (cinnamon and nutmeg), orchard fruit, grape skin, polished oak and butterscotch. Grape skin and red wine tannic touches, with spiced butter and shortbread.

name: Redbreast 199725 Year Old Cream Sherry Cask The Whisky Exchange Exclusive
characters: Apple, Dark Chocolate, Orange, Thyme, Blackcurrant, Coffee
nose: Caramelised pecans, walnut liqueur, honey roasted cashews. Plums, figs, raisins and dried cranberries. There’s a green side that you sometimes find in old pot still whiskey with blackberry leaves, vine leaves and a little spearmint.
palate: Peanut brittle, a few dried chillis, some black peppercorns. Lots of umami with oxidised sherry notes, warm earth, dried shiitakes, barley miso, and cacao nibs. Then hazelnuts, liquorice, nutmeg, bitter oranges and crème de cassis. A dash of water brings out big chocolaty notes and more nutty sherry character.
finish: Long, with a nice tension between oak tannins and milk chocolate.
flavour_note: Apple, Dark Chocolate, Orange, Thyme, Blackcurrant, Coffee Caramelised pecans, walnut liqueur, honey roasted cashews. Plums, figs, raisins and dried cranberries. There’s a green side that you sometimes find in old pot still whiskey with blackberry leaves, vine leaves and a little spearmint. Peanut brittle, a few dried chillis, some black peppercorns. Lots of umami with oxidised sherry notes, warm earth, dried shiitakes, barley miso, and cacao nibs. Then hazelnuts, liquorice, nutmeg, bitter oranges and crème de cassis. A dash of water brings out big chocolaty notes and more nutty sherry character. Long, with a nice tension between oak tannins and milk chocolate.

name: Yellow Spot 12 Year Old
nose: Mown hay and cracked black pepper. Red bell peppers, nutmeg, clove oil and green tea. Sweet honey & peaches from the Malaga casks
palate: Honey sweetness with pot still spices. Flavours of fresh coffee, creamy milk chocolate and Crème Brûlée. Notes of red apples and toasted oak. Its finish is sophisticated and complex with a sweetness throughout, followed by a mix of red grape and dry barley upon exit
finish: The sweet spice persists after the soft fruit disappears.
reviews: Excellent Whisky!!! We had this while in Scotland and it is SO smooth! There is a sweetness right at the end that is delicious!! || Delicious || Spectacular whiskey from Ireland. They have really upped their game. Very smooth and has excellent aromas. || Amazing whiskey. Similar to have neat better than XO cognac with a good cup of coffee || Buttery smooth with a subtle bite. Really enjoying this Father's Day gift.
flavour_note: Mown hay and cracked black pepper. Red bell peppers, nutmeg, clove oil and green tea. Sweet honey & peaches from the Malaga casks Honey sweetness with pot still spices. Flavours of fresh coffee, creamy milk chocolate and Crème Brûlée. Notes of red apples and toasted oak. Its finish is sophisticated and complex with a sweetness throughout, followed by a mix of red grape and dry barley upon exit The sweet spice persists after the soft fruit disappears.

name: The Whistler Irish Whiskey Oloroso Finish

name: Jameson Caskmates Stout Edition
characters: Milk Chocolate, Marzipan, Oak, Coffee, Butterscotch
nose: Crisp orchard fruits like green apples and pears, mild pot-still spices.
finish: Long and sweet with milk chocolate and butterscotch.
reviews: Suits me,smooth creamy slightly sweet.Right up there. || verry smooth you can really see the stout barrel influence here a verry good dram worth a try for sure || Mmmm good you can really get the Stout barrel influence awesome. would have a dram again in a heart beat again || I think Jameson’s are tapping into the bourbon market & making it look like an accident. It’s a lovely whiskey on the nose there is some bourbon notes, oak a little char could be from the toasted hops or dark malt left in the barrel , It’s very creamy on the pallet some Werthers original in there, and super smooth especially for the age. Only 3 years I’ve heard. a little bitter stout taste on the finish. Well done definitely buy again . || Light and smooth. Totally must try.
flavour_note: Milk Chocolate, Marzipan, Oak, Coffee, Butterscotch Crisp orchard fruits like green apples and pears, mild pot-still spices. Long and sweet with milk chocolate and butterscotch.

name: Jameson
nose: Mellow pot still whiskey with toasted wood and sherry undertones.
reviews: I have lived in Ireland for few years and had Jameson on many occasions, I had a tour of Jameson distillery in Bow Street, Dublin. For some reason I never thought much of this whiskey, I was more of a Bushmills drinker. I bought a bottle last year and I was very surprised. This whisky is quite mellow, not very light- but quite smooth, lots of toffee, vanilla, milk chocolate, buttery flavor. You can taste the presence of maize- that's right!- as one of ingredients. Very enjoyable on ice. This is a great buy in this price range, to me way better than Bushmills Original. || Smooth raisins at a great price. || I started off my whisky journey some years back with Glenmorangie, which I still regularly drink. This was my first time drinking Jameson, I only got it because it was on offer, and thought being Irish I'd try an Irish stable. Wow so underwhelming. Practically no finish, I had to double check I'd drunk some. Trying to figure out the nose, all I got seemed like ethanol, and the hit of my stomach the next day was reminiscent of knacker drinking Southern Comfort in my teenage years. Definitely won't be buying again. Think I'll try getting a bottle of Tyrconnell single malt next time instead.. || Vanilla nose which continues through. Very smooth but packs an afterburn. Doesn’t have a complex mix of tastes. Satisfying nonetheless. Very short finish, tempting you to pour another one! || Consistently delicious and value for money whisky. At the beginning of the end of the world, as the sirens began to wail, I think I'd reach for this one.
flavour_note: Oak, Toast, Sherry Mellow pot still whiskey with toasted wood and sherry undertones. Incredibly smooth.

name: Boann Marsala Finish Single Pot Still Irish Whiskey
flavour_note: Vanilla, Lemon, Sultana, Oak, Honey

name: The Legendary Dark Silkie Irish Whiskey
characters: Smoke, Toffee, Tobacco, Pear, Dark Chocolate, Caramel
flavour_note: Smoke, Toffee, Tobacco, Pear, Dark Chocolate, Caramel

name: Teeling Single Pot Still
characters: Cinnamon, Caramel, Toast, Blackberry, Milk Chocolate, Apple
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Caramel, Toast, Blackberry, Milk Chocolate, Apple

name: The Pogues Blended Irish Whiskey
reviews: Not bad , smooth not much alcohol afrerburn, but not much else either || Wow taste buds exited. This whisky is really nice tasting . Leave a nice after effect from the first taste. And is very pleasent on the palette. If you thought about this brand of whisky then give it a sample you'll enjoy the experience || smooth and full of toffee i loved it || It’s not unusual to be loved by anyone but it is unusual to have your Whiskey taste like Twiglets and Battenberg. || As others have commented, nice smooth whiskey. Easy to drink .

name: Redbreast 21 Year Old
reviews: Yes I have tried it a number of times and have found it an excellent taste and share it with a mate whenever I drink it.
flavour_note: Pineapple, Pear, Shortbread, Vanilla, Pastries

name: Powers Gold Distiller's Cut
reviews:
My favorite Irish whiskey by far. Visiting Ireland often for work, a local friend suggested it,& from the moment I tried it, I loved it. Unique potent taste that distinguishes it from other Irish whiskeys. Always have a bottle in my cellar || This is without doubt, (Distillers Cut) to the best whiskey I have ever tasted. I have for a long time been a drinker of Gold Label among others and never missed an opportunity to buy a bottle or two whenever I found it. My best friend who sadly died last year lived at Trallispean  Beach ( South of Baltimore) and whenever I visited him two or three times a year, always had a bottle of Gold Label on the mantle piece which he bought for my visits and affectionately described as “Holy water”
As long as this brand is available in England I will be buying and drinking it - I hope Tesco’s will continue stocking it

name: Red Spot 15 Year Old Irish Whiskey
Method and Madness Japanese Chestnut Cask Finish
characters: Coffee, Almond, Dried Fruit, Liquorice root, Orange, Mint
flavour_note: Coffee, Almond, Dried Fruit, Liquorice root, Orange, Mint

name: Dingle La Le Bride Single Malt
characters: Bread, Fennel, Black Pepper, Malt, Honey
flavour_note: Bread, Fennel, Black Pepper, Malt, Honey

name: Two Stacks 12 Year Old Single Grain
characters: Vanilla, Pastries, Lychee, Coconut, Milk Chocolate
flavour_note: Vanilla, Pastries, Lychee, Coconut, Milk Chocolate

name: Two Stacks Single Grain Double Barrel
characters: Vanilla, Dried Fruit, Orange, Pear, Almond
reviews: This is a lovely, drinkable blend and very flavoursome without being harsh. It's obviously a light whisky, both in colour and alcohol content but doesn't lose anything in flavour because of this. I'm no expert but I feel that the sherry barrel comes through, as does the vanilla and almond in the aftertaste. I'll definitely be buying this again.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Dried Fruit, Orange, Pear, Almond

name: Lambay Small Batch Blended Irish Whiskey
reviews: Bought this for the first time a couple of weeks ago. It is delicious and I can't recommend it enough as an excellent whiskey for its price range || One of the best whiskeys I've ever had. Probably my favorite.
flavour_note: Floral, citrus and lingering spiciness. Spiciness with lingering sweetness.

name: Tullamore Dew
reviews: Light and smooth on the palette, || Value for money is what best describes this easy smooth Irish. A first alcoholic impression with some fruit notes behind but after having a taste the sweet apple and caramel will show clearly to the nose. Even if it doesn’t have a long persistence in mouth, there are the promised fruit notes and some vanilla with a bit spicy end. || I just bought a bottle today, and i love it. The smell is so fresh and fruity... and the palate too! Silky and smooth. I taste caramel, coconut, pineapple, and some spicy herbs. For the price, you can't get much better drams than this. Totally worth it. || In that low-mid price range (Jameson, TD, Ballantines, JW red, Chivas regal etc.) it best matches my taste. Smooth taste, easy drinking. I enjoy drinking TD most of those mentioned above. Nevertheless I assume it's always a personal preference/taste, which is important. || Initial sharp, fiery hit smoothes out and softens. Decent with both sipping and mixing qualities. Price is attractive for low to mid range pockets .
flavour_note: Apple, Blackcurrant, Vanilla

name: JJ Corry The Flintlock Batch 116 Year Old
Shortcross 5 Year Old Distiller’s Duo
characters: Vanilla, Oak, Apple, Tobacco, Honeysuckle, Barley
flavour_note: Vanilla, Oak, Apple, Tobacco, Honeysuckle, Barley

name: Dingle Lunasa Single Malt

name: Egan's 2012 Vintage GrainBot.2022
reviews:
A beautiful, smooth golden velvet whiskey. Very satisfying with hints of vanilla, & with a rich undertone of the bourbon cask that it was aged in.  So smooth that it's strength is a surprise; ( my 2009/2019 casked/bottled) one was 46%.
Would certainly seek this out again! || FANTASTIC
flavour_note: Malt, Honey, Apple, Shortbread, Toffee

name: Bushmills 2000 Port CaskCauseway Collection

name: Roe & Co Blended Irish Whiskey
nose: Creamy, delightfully fragrant and remarkably rounded with notes of soft spice and mellow spun sugar along with warm hints of woody vanilla.
palate: The quality and perfect balance of the blend is immediately apparent on the palate through its velvety texture and sweet flavours including spiced pears and vanilla.
finish: Lingering and gentle, ending with a light creaminess.
reviews: I tried this for the first time whilst in Ireland, to be honest I would normally turn my nose up at any other than that which hails from the Scotland. What a belter of a for the price! Smooth as silk. Now my go to. || Amazingly smooth whiskey. Simple & pure. The best I have had in 60 years! || Solid whisky , price point is excellent! || Had this last night and it is sensational. The fruit experience on your tongue actually made me think of coconut but pear is accurate. || This is one of the worst whiskeys I have ever tried.
flavour_note: Pear, Vanilla, Cream Creamy, delightfully fragrant and remarkably rounded with notes of soft spice and mellow spun sugar along with warm hints of woody vanilla. The quality and perfect balance of the blend is immediately apparent on the palate through its velvety texture and sweet flavours including spiced pears and vanilla. Lingering and gentle, ending with a light creaminess.

name: Paddy
reviews: Not good . Very bad experience || I have tried about 50 brands of blended whisky, i love tullamore dew and jameson, but today for first time i tasted PADDY and i was surprised.... It's better then both || This a nice whiskey especially when it has strong competition! || Love it. Very easy to drink with a smooth finish. || Smooth, nice finish. Best served neat. Very mellow. Completely enjoyable.

name: Redbreast 12 Year Old Cask StrengthBatch B1-23
reviews: Very tasty whisky, intense and flavorful. Loses a star because it does show some sulfur notes, and it’s not something I like in whiskeys. It’s not off putting, and others may not even notice. I’d happily recommend this and will certainly be replacing this bottle when it’s over.
flavour_note: Mango, Banana, Orange, Cinnamon, Nutmeg

name: The Legendary Silkie Irish Whiskey
nose: Fresh and malty, brisk like green apples, opens to be more honeyed with a gentle butteryness.
reviews: Amazed that the review does not get the hint of smoke at the end and judges it zero on that. It's clearly there. A more interesting whiskey from this company, showing that they are learning. Leaving it at 46 percent allows for more interest as drops of water open up the different notes. A great effort from this distillery that is finally getting to make it's own products. || Myself and 2 friends drank the bottle earlier this week. We all thought it was very smooth and so drinkable, we will defo be buying this again. Also it doesn't taste like a 46% Whiskey, we would highly recommend this lovely Whiskey .
flavour_note: Malt, Honey, Apple Fresh and malty, brisk like green apples, opens to be more honeyed with a gentle butteryness.

name: Red Spot 199131 Year Old Marsala Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Tobacco, Prunes, Blackcurrant, Peach, Cacao, Mint
flavour_note: Tobacco, Prunes, Blackcurrant, Peach, Cacao, Mint

name: Connacht Single Malt WhiskeyBatch 1
characters: Almond, Walnut, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Honey, Malt
reviews: Next to Jamison Crested this is my favorite Irish water of life. || Cracked open this Bottle earlier. Simply a gorgeous Dram . I was a bit apprehensive about the Star Anise but it blends in beautifully with the Honey & Almond . That is without doubt a fabulous Dram . It blows away the Redbreast 12 which has always been on my shelf . Exciting times ahead for this Distillery . || Simply delicious || Lovely, sweet, honey flavoured malt. this would be very impressive for an established distillery, never mind a new one like Connacht!
flavour_note: Almond, Walnut, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Honey, Malt

name: Teeling 199129 Year Old Rum Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Papaya, Pineapple, Mango, Honey, Lime, Oak
nose: Gummi bears and golden syrup with a pile of peelable citrus: tangerines, clementines and satsumas. Mango and pineapple notes develop: both fresh and dried. A background of golden syrup and honey adds extra sweetness and complexity.
palate: Fresh fruit leads: the mango and pineapple of the nose with extra guava and a touch of yuzu. Brown sugar sweetness hides underneath along with a touch of vanilla and soft spice.
finish: A touch of heat fades to leave jelly baby fruitiness, damp oak and gentle spice.
flavour_note: Papaya, Pineapple, Mango, Honey, Lime, Oak Gummi bears and golden syrup with a pile of peelable citrus: tangerines, clementines and satsumas. Mango and pineapple notes develop: both fresh and dried. A background of golden syrup and honey adds extra sweetness and complexity. Fresh fruit leads: the mango and pineapple of the nose with extra guava and a touch of yuzu. Brown sugar sweetness hides underneath along with a touch of vanilla and soft spice. A touch of heat fades to leave jelly baby fruitiness, damp oak and gentle spice.

name: Sailor's Home The Journey
characters: Cinnamon, Vanilla, Custard, Apricot, Apple, Banana
reviews:
Great Whiskey for the price point.
As you would expect from an Irish Whiskey, a smooth and gentle dram, with an excellent finish.
flavour_note: Cinnamon, Vanilla, Custard, Apricot, Apple, Banana

name: Kirker & Greer Shamrock
characters: White Pepper, Vanilla, Apple, Caramel, Milk Chocolate, Toffee
reviews: I had it at Maddens Bar in Belfast at the recommendation of the bartender. It was so good I flew a bottle home with me. || A high quality Irish blend. || a great sipping whisky that goes down well || A high quality blend that blows Jameson out of the water! Definitely worth trying. || I really enjoyed this, definitely one I would buy again. I've not much experience with Irish whisky, since Jamson's growing up, this bottle defiantly has given me more curiosity to check into Irish whisky
flavour_note: White Pepper, Vanilla, Apple, Caramel, Milk Chocolate, Toffee

name: Dunville's 12 Year OldPX Cask
reviews:
Very good .. shame the 10 YO isn’t available anymore was also
Excellent

name: McConnell's 5 Year Old Irish Whisky
characters: Milk Chocolate, Cinnamon, Vanilla, Nutmeg, Black Pepper, Oak
reviews: Usually a Red Breast drinker, but gave this a try - really impressed, very smooth with great oak and vanilla notes, bottle is really heavy and beautiful - very high quality for the price
flavour_note: Milk Chocolate, Cinnamon, Vanilla, Nutmeg, Black Pepper, Oak

name: Glendalough Pot Still
reviews: Smooth with a subtle seeetness
flavour_note: Honey, Malt, Oak, Ginger

name: Hinch 5 Year Old Double Wood Irish Whiskey
reviews: With a little water, this becomes silky, fragrant and a little spicy. Beautiful stuff for a 5 year old. Finish is caramalised toffee with a little banana. It's a steal at this price. My rating based on price & age. || Fairly simple nose, spirity oaky finish, some breadth, forward acidity on the tip of the tongue, yet to place its value in the supply chain, more time in cask to be encouraged.

name: Teeling Single Malt Whiskey
characters: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Lemon, Clove, Oak
nose: Vibrant with notes of melon, figs, toffee and lemon.
palate: More pineapple kubes, icing sugar, lemon bonbons and sponge cake with butter icing, with granny smith apples for some balancing sharpness and some cloves for bitterness and spice.
finish: Long with sweetness in harmony with dry tannins from the wood.
reviews: After visiting the Teeling distillery, listening tothe story and doing some tastings, i can conclude hands down that this single malt pot still is the soul of Dublin and one of my favourites. Oh, that finish!!! || This is my current go-to whiskey. The finish on this whiskey is the best I've ever experienced. I always buy a second bottle before the first is half gone. || Smooth and gentle. Good price point. Great for Saturday nights while watching a movie or reading a book. || Exceptionally smooth; will always keep a bottle on the top shelve. || Love it! For the price Jameson Caskmates kills it
flavour_note: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Lemon, Clove, Oak Vibrant with notes of melon, figs, toffee and lemon. More pineapple kubes, icing sugar, lemon bonbons and sponge cake with butter icing, with granny smith apples for some balancing sharpness and some cloves for bitterness and spice. Long with sweetness in harmony with dry tannins from the wood.

name: McConnell's 5 Year Old Irish WhiskySherry Cask
nose: Dried Figs and currants followed by Christmas spices such as nutmeg and cinnamon, dark chocolate, and a hint of fresh leather.
palate: Demerara sugar, dark ripe cherries and black raspberry followed by bitter dark chocolate shavings and rich red apples.
finish: Lingering oak notes, with a hint of leather and subtle clove spice.
reviews: Love this Whisky! Top draw || Great Whisky straight from the bowels of the notorious Crumlin Prison. LOVE the Sherrywood || The jammy dark fruit flavours really stand out in this whisky, along with the almost savoury dark chocolate notes, with an unctousness beyond it's 5 years. Well worth a try.
flavour_note: Dried Figs and currants followed by Christmas spices such as nutmeg and cinnamon, dark chocolate, and a hint of fresh leather. Demerara sugar, dark ripe cherries and black raspberry followed by bitter dark chocolate shavings and rich red apples. Lingering oak notes, with a hint of leather and subtle clove spice.

name: Green Spot 201310 Year Old Bourbon Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Vanilla, Pear, Apple, Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Orange
nose: Layers of fruity apple: sour green, sweet red and green, and apple candy. Vanilla cream, buttery pastry and softly spiced apple-pie filling follow. The fruitiness continues with gummi bears and a touch of ripe pear. The vanilla becomes more complex, showing tonka bean florality, spice and coconut.
palate: Crisp fruit also leads on the palate, with the gummi bears reappearing and diving into a basket of apples. Spice builds, with cinnamon and nutmeg joined by anise and mint fondant. Sponge cake with candied peel and polished oak develops.
finish: Juicy apples, pears, mango and candied citrus, with gentle spice and gentle vanilla.
flavour_note: Vanilla, Pear, Apple, Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Orange Layers of fruity apple: sour green, sweet red and green, and apple candy. Vanilla cream, buttery pastry and softly spiced apple-pie filling follow. The fruitiness continues with gummi bears and a touch of ripe pear. The vanilla becomes more complex, showing tonka bean florality, spice and coconut. Crisp fruit also leads on the palate, with the gummi bears reappearing and diving into a basket of apples. Spice builds, with cinnamon and nutmeg joined by anise and mint fondant. Sponge cake with candied peel and polished oak develops. Juicy apples, pears, mango and candied citrus, with gentle spice and gentle vanilla.

name: Dunville's Three Crowns Whiskey
characters: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Malt, Butterscotch, Caramel, Walnut
nose: Sweet and smooth with caramel and butterscotch overtones.
palate: Stays smooth with initial sweetness balancing with grain and malt characters supported by oak influence. Friendly to the palate, very drinkable.
finish: Subtle notes of walnut and dried fruits come through in the soft, lingering finish leaving you with thoughts of vanilla pods.
reviews: I was gifted a couple of bottles of Dunville's whiskey at Christmas, and even though I'm not the greatest Whiskey lover, these went down rather well! || Okay for drinking on the rocks or mixing but quiet rough around the edges as a sipper. Bushmills Black Bush is much better for almost half the price. Wouldn’t buy this again.
flavour_note: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Malt, Butterscotch, Caramel, Walnut Sweet and smooth with caramel and butterscotch overtones. Stays smooth with initial sweetness balancing with grain and malt characters supported by oak influence. Friendly to the palate, very drinkable. Subtle notes of walnut and dried fruits come through in the soft, lingering finish leaving you with thoughts of vanilla pods.

name: Knappogue Castle 12 Year Old Marsala Finish
flavour_note: Toffee, Caramel, Malt, Meat, Apple

name: Clonakilty Port Cask Irish Whiskey
reviews: A very nice light whiskey, the fruit develops well in your mouth, a tiny amount of peat in the smell for some reason || Quality whisky smooth on the nose and the palate, peppers come in and stay for the fade out || A really nice dram || Excellent whiskey. Very smooth and complex. What a surprise. One of the better new faces in Irish distilling.
flavour_note: Peach, Orange, Lemon, Caramel, Vanilla

name: Method and Madness Hickory Wood FinishExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cacao, Almond, Honeycomb, Caramel, Smoke, Dark Chocolate
nose: Immediately filled with aromas of candied bacon, sweet hickory smoke, honeycomb and pecan pie, the nose then brings heaps of caramelised apples, autumn leaves, slightly singed barbecued pineapple and burnt caramel.
palate: Ground ginger and cloves jump forward, followed by dried figs, stewed plums, savoury oak spice and far away bonfires. Green sticks, smoked almonds and dark chocolate build underneath.
finish: Lingering notes if rich mocha ice cream and treacle tart.
flavour_note: Cacao, Almond, Honeycomb, Caramel, Smoke, Dark Chocolate Immediately filled with aromas of candied bacon, sweet hickory smoke, honeycomb and pecan pie, the nose then brings heaps of caramelised apples, autumn leaves, slightly singed barbecued pineapple and burnt caramel. Ground ginger and cloves jump forward, followed by dried figs, stewed plums, savoury oak spice and far away bonfires. Green sticks, smoked almonds and dark chocolate build underneath. Lingering notes if rich mocha ice cream and treacle tart.
